Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have completed for you, my Sons, this book, which is the last in science of medicine with its complement, and have brought to an end therein according to his exposition and his own declarations, it has seemed meet to me to complete it for you together with this Treatise which is a part of operation, that is, surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since the operation with the hand lies in our region and time, completely private until perhaps the science of it perished and its trace was cut off, leaving nothing but precise descriptions in ancient books, which were altered by hands; and errors and hesitation occurred until his intentions were closed and his course extended. It has seemed meet to me to vivify it with the arrangement of this Treatise concerning it according to the position and declaration and abbreviation. And to obtain forgiveness with the forms of the cautery and other instruments of the operation: which is done by addition from the declaration and by hastening what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The cause why a good artisan with his hand is not found in our time is: because the art of medicine is long, and it is necessary for the author thereof to exercise himself before that in the science of anatomy, as Galen narrates, until he knows the supports of the members, their forms, their conjunctions, and separations, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, sinews, and their number, and their emergence, and veins, their pulsatile and quiet states, and the places of their exit.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for that reason Hippocrates said, "Name without knowledge is much, and name without work is little, especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have indeed already spoken of that in the introduction to this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since he who is not aware of what we have said concerning anatomy will not profit, but will rather fall into error, which leads to the harm of men: as I have seen many among those who are trained in this science and boast of it without knowledge and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	For I have seen a stupid physician cut into a scrofulous abscess on a woman's neck, and he incised certain arteries in the neck: wherefore the woman's blood flowed until she died in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I have seen another physician who attempted to extract a stone from a man who had one form the age of stones were large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	He therefore approached him and extracted the stone along with a piece of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Wherefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I myself had indeed been called to extract the stone: and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the patient that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I have seen another physician who received a fee from one of our Dukes for his medical services: and it happened to the black eunuch who was with him that he suffered a fracture near the heel in his thigh bone: and the physician, with his ignorance, hastened and bound the fracture over the wound with bandages and strong splints, and did not release the wound from its constriction.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he discharged him according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards he discharged him after a few days, and commanded him not to loosen the bandage: and he stood thus until the abscess on his thigh and foot burst, and he came to destruction.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was therefore called to him, and hastened to untie the ligament; and there ensued tranquility, and he escaped from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	Truly, the corruption was now confirmed in the member, and I could not arrest it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore, the corruption ceased to wander through the member, until it perished.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who pierced the cancerous abscess: and it became ulcerated after a few days, until the wickedness of it increased with its lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	Which is because when a cancer is pure from melancholic humour, then it should not be reached with iron at all, unless it is in a part that can tolerate it, so that the entire thing may be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for this reason, my Son, you must know that the operation with the hand is divided into two parts: namely, the operation associated with safety; and the operation with which danger is present in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already excited in every place of this book where an operation is performed that involves terror and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore, you must beware of this and dismiss it, so that the foolish may not find a way to speak about it and dishonor it.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore, receive the measure with solicitude and protection, and your sick with facility and firmness, and use the better way leading through the grace of God to salvation and a worthy succession: and dismiss terrible diseases that are difficult to cure: and lift your souls from what makes you fear, that hesitation may not enter upon you in your faith and well-being.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more enduring for your glory, and higher in this world, and finally for your quantities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galenus has already said this in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	You shall not treat evil disease: lest you be called a physician of evil.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	Now we divide this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter First.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	On the cautery with fire, and the cautery with sharp medicine, divided and ordered from head to feet, and the forms of the cautery instruments and tools: and everything necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter Second.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On incision and puncture, phlebotomy and venesection, and wounds: and the extraction of arrows and similar objects: and the entire chapter ordered by the forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Third.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration, dislocation, and the cure of torsion and similar conditions: the chapter ordered from head to feet, and by the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God Alone Be Glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	Albucasis's Surgical Treatise.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On the Use and Harm of the Cautery: for which complexions it is suitable, and at what time: whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Head I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But First Before I recall the operation with him, I must say of the quality of his horses, and of its injuries: and in what complexion it is presented.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say that the discourse concerning the quality of Cauterius' horse and its injuries is a lengthy and subtle science, and a hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	And a multitude of wise men spoke on this matter, and disagreed. And I find their words insufficient for me, fearing the length.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say that Cauterius applies his remedy universally to all complexions, which are either with matter or without matter: except for two complexions, which are the hot complexion without matter, and the dry complexion without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	In the hot and dry complexion with matter, they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	For some said that Cauterius is beneficial in the hot and dry complexion with matter.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite, namely that Cauterius is not appropriate in illness arising from heat and dryness: for the nature of fire is heat, and it is inappropriate to heal with something hot and dry when the condition is already hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the opposite said: that through Cauterius, benefit is derived in every hot and dry illness that occurs in human bodies: for when you compare the human body and its humours to the complexion of fire, you find the human body to be cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I say through his words: for by experience I have often detected this.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in seipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterizatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super veritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if I were to tell you the secret of its action in fire and the quality of its operation in expelling diseases from the bodies, I would demonstrate it to you with a philosophical and persuasive argument, which might sharpen your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And you shall know, O sons, that they disagree on the time when it is fitting to make the cautery and prefer a better time.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that the cautery is fitting at all times; for harm that occurs due to timing is overcome by the benefit drawn from using the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if the cautery is due to pains from necessary, strong, and rapid pains that do not tolerate delay: for fear is had that some greater harm might occur, which would be more detrimental than the minor harm caused by the delay.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And let it not enter your minds, O sons, that which they do not consider, except the common and stupid physicians, namely, that the condition cured by the cautery is not always subject to a relapse: and they add what follows, and the matter is not as they imagine. For the cautery is not used unless in place of medicine, which alters the complexion and dries up the humors that are the causes of pain.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Yet the cautery often surpasses medicine through its velocity of action, strength of operation, and vigor of dominion: and it is possible that the condition returns at some hour according to the complexion of the patient, the location of the disease, and its own virtue: and what is prepared in his body from the aggregation of superfluous elements within him: and what reaches him in acquisition from foods and similar causes, unless a condition arises where the cautery is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A disease of subtlety in a member with few superfluities and humours, such as the cautery of a tooth, on account of pain, and similar to that, it is possible for that pain not to return therein.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this happens in few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But the speech of the common people again is that the cautery is the last remedy of medicine, and it is a correct speech: not at what they intend in that: for they believe that it is not a cure that can compare with medicine nor with other remedies after the occasion of the cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the truth is contrary to that and their intent, for the cautery being the last remedy of medicine is not [used] unless when after administering means of cure in some disease they do not effect a cure; then at the end we administer the cautery and it does effect a cure: thus falls away the idea that the cautery is the last remedy of medicine, not according to the intent which the common people and many credulous physicians understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that the cautery with gold is better than the cautery with iron: and they did not say this except on account of the equality of gold and the sublimity of its substance: and they said that the place of the cautery does not produce pus.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	Indeed this is not absolutely true: for I have already tested it and found that it does not do this in some bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the cautery with gold is good, and better than that with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	Indeed, when you apply the cautery of fire to gold, you do not see clearly when it is burned according to the quantity you wish, because of the rust of the gold: and when it approaches the cold, and if you add ignition to it again, it liquefies in the fire and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Why the craftsman falls into occupation and thereby a cauterization with iron is made more swiftly and closely to us by reason of this straightness for operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I have indeed arranged this Chapter on Cauterization according to chapters, and have ordered it from head to foot, so that the寻求者 may find what he wishes from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	¶ On the Method of Cauterizing at the Coronal Suture.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This cauterization is applied to the dominion of moisture and cold over the brain. These two causes lead to excess fluidity, and an abundance of fluid flow from the head to the eye and ear regions, as well as an increase in sleepiness, toothache, throat pain, and universally all diseases resulting from cold, such as paralysis, hydrocephalus, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar conditions.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is to apply it to the patient: let the head be treated with medicinal leeches for three nights or four, according to the strength of the patient, their age, and their habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then order him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands in a square position, so that his hands are placed on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm on the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Whenever therefore your middle finger passes over it, mark that place with the cauterization.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then the Olive Cautery with Fire: of which this is the form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it over the marked spot with the incised mark, using a descent by which your hand may be gradually guided, and you shall rotate it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then lift your hand quickly, and observe the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see already revealed the quantity of the head of alkali or the quantity of zeburbi, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat the operation with the iron itself, or with another one if this has been cooled: until you see the bones, which I have told you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take something from the salt, and dissolve it in water, and apply it to the cloth, and place it over the spot: and leave it there for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place the cloth soaked in oil over it, and leave it there until the burn eschar is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with fourfold ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have said that the more an injury remains open, the more pus it emits; therefore, it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them have said that the skin should be cauterized down to the bone: and the cauterization should be maintained until something of thickness of bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then the burnt area on the bone is scraped away, and then it is treated.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that with the cautery one must proceed to the very end until it impresses a mark like a crest in the os, so that the os falls, which is as if formed like kirate: or an instrument which women put into the infused little alphabet: and they think that vapors of the head are exhaling from this place and the wound will be let out open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be cared for until it is consolidated.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	But to me these two species of cautery do not seem entirely different except in some people according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And let it come out, for me it is better with the health of itself.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened by the disruption of its natural continuity: as we have testified in other limbs. And especially when the head is naturally weak and feeble. And indeed, the first species of cautery is more safe and better with me, and I use it. Therefore, I operate with it for the sake of health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing the head when there is pain throughout the head.
Caput III.	Head III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When there is chronic pain throughout the head, and this condition persists in the patient, he uses hellebore, colocynth, head purgatives, oils, and plasters.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized with the cautery we have described, and none of those things are applied to it: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of the patient is strong by nature and not weak, and he finds intense cold: then cauterize with another cautery beneath it lightly.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it over every horn of the head with a cauterization, nor let the skin pass through, and let the quantity covered be as we have narrated.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with one cauterization at the back of its head, at a place called vas: and this is the place where the suction device is placed: raise your mature tool here, and do not uncover the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For it found the sick one suffering from a severe pain, different from the pain of other cauterizations of the heads of all.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will say this cauterization in its place: and it must be a cauterization with which the horns of the head are cauterized, and its back more finely with a cauterization with which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in headache, both with burned medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain occurs in part of the head with soda, or extends to the eye, and is evacuated with cleansing medicines for the head, and the remaining treatment is administered as I said in the divisions of diseases, and it does not include all that: then cauterization in this is according to two modes: either cauterization with burning sharp medicine: or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	The cauterization with burning sharp medicine is as follows: take one tooth of garlic, peel it, and cut off the ends from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the place of pain at the time of phlebotomy with a broad lancet until a spot under the skin is made where the garlic tooth is taken.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Therefore insert it beneath the skin until it is hidden; then tie it with a suitable ligature and remove it after fifteen hours, and take out the garlic and let the ligature off for two or three days. Afterwards place it beneath the fat until the area produces pus, and then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with certain burning medicines, which I have written about in the twelfth treatise, On Burning Medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Cauterization of it with iron is to be done in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Cauterization by Fire, whose form is as follows.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called Clavilis: for the shape of its head is like that of a nail, in which there is a slight curve, and in its middle there is a small prominence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it over the area and hold your hand there: and turn the iron slowly with speed, and let the amount that is burned be according to the thickness of the skin, as its half.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift your hand so that the artery below is not burned, and no bleeding occurs.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then immerse the garlic in salty water, and place it over the area, and leave it for three days. Then place the garlic with butter. Afterwards care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this hemi-craniac with the secondary extremity of the Cauterius.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And beware of making an incision in the artery in this headache, not one that is properly old.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in ancient headache.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you treat a headache, follow what we said in the previous cure and what we said in the divisions of diseases. And if the treatment is not effective: and you see from the disease that what we said with the first cautery and medicine, or with cautery by fire, is insufficient for him, then you must brand the cautery knife until it whitens after you mark the place of pain with a line, whose length is the half of a finger, or as much as that. And withdraw your hand once, and press it until you incise the artery, and proceed until you reach the opening.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	You must, however, beware of the continuity of the jawbone, which moves during chewing, so that the side or the nerve that moves it is not burned, lest a spasm occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And be mindful of the care and caution regarding the flow of blood in the artery that has been severed.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For there is a fear in its severance, and particularly for one who does not know what he is doing and is neither studious nor experienced: and he should desist from the operation at once.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I shall proceed with the reminder of the regulation of the flow of blood occurring from the artery according to its proper mode and place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	And if you see from the disease that this cautery is insufficient for him, and you observe that the patient's body can tolerate the cautery in the middle of the head, as we have described, care for the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer the Cautery, which we have said in the chapter on the extraction of an artery with a Cautery having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For the cautery is better and more effective than this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	¶ Concerning the method of cauterizing for pain in the ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain in the ear occurs from cold, and is treated with dissolution and the other treatment we have said in the division, and the pain does not cease, then use the Cautery with fire: and it is that which is called Punctum, whose form is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then prick the ear after its cauterization around the entire circumference of the ear as it is turned; or around both sides if the pain is in both ears.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And move the Cautery from the root of the ear slightly after marking the places with infused oil: and let the quantity of the Cautery be ten pricks in each ear, and about that.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then treat those places until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	¶ Concerning the method of cauterizing for Tortura.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	Tortura, which is treated with cauterization, is not anything other than conditions that arise from phlegm, as we have said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And apply the appropriate cauterization for the species that arises from drying out and nerve spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this species of torture with fumigations, and head purges, and gargles, and if your treatment does not bring about recovery, then it is necessary to cauterize the patient three times with Cauterias: one at the root of the ear, and the second slightly below its proper place, and the third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cauterium on the opposite side of the sick part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not occur except in the part which appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterization is to cauterize the upper end of the ear directly at the base of the horn of the head: and at another time, whose length shall be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And withdraw your hand with the cauterium until it burns a quantity of skin half its thickness.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cauterium, and it is a species from the surgical knife, whose form was previously mentioned; yet it should not be too thin, as you can see: and it should be a knife of somewhat excessive thickness.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then treat the area with what preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	On the manner of cauterizing in Ancient Apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When ancient apoplexy is confirmed, and you treat it with what we have said, and if your treatment does not bring about recovery, and the patient does not have a fever, then cauterize him four times over each horn of his head, and with one cauterium in the middle of his head, as we have said, and with one at the back of his head, according to what has been previously mentioned: and the manner of cauterization should be according to what has been previously stated.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	And it is also cauterized with a Cautery over the mouth of the stomach: and it is more ultimate.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then it is to be treated with what has preceded.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in Obliuione.
Caput IX.	Head 9.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary to give first great hen eggs in broth, and brain-purifying pills.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the whole head of the sick person, and apply the plaster described in the treatise on plasters to the back of his head: and apply it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This is the measure of the Cautery: and do it according to the same order that I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore he is cured by it, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not, then apply three cauterizations on the back part of his head, which should descend from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye: and place between all cauterizations the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat with the Cautery as what has preceded.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If, however, you wish to add and the patient is able to tolerate it, then apply the Cautery in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you wish to add, then cauterize it over both horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat it until it is cured: and apply the Cautery with oil in the form described earlier.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the manner of cauterizing in paralysis and softening.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary to proceed with the purification of the head using hyssop, and with what we have said before.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then scrape the patient's head: afterwards cauterize it with a cauterization in the middle of the head, and with a cauterization over all the horns of the head, and three times over the occipital bones.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If, however, you need to apply a cauterization for the softening of the body in multiple places, and the patient is weak but the illness is strong: then cauterize it four times over the vertebral columns, and the last time with a stronger cauterization until the skin burns as much as possible from it, and raise your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for it until it is healed: and thus perform the Oleation cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the manner of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic is not cauterized, except for one whose epilepsy is caused by phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore, you must purify his brain first using hyssop, and with the other treatment we have said in the division: when the patient is severe or tolerates the administration of medicines well.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If, however, it is a child who does not tolerate medicines, then a gargling solution and chewing substances for brain purification are administered, before all that over many days with the improvement of food.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head, thereafter cauterize it with one cautery in the middle of the head, according to what preceded in manner: and cauterize his occiput with another cautery, and over all the horns of his head cauterize.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the patient is strong and tolerable, then cauterize it with the cauteries which I said in one having paralysis, and softening of the body over the vertebrae of the neck and the vertebrae of the back: and let the cautery be oleata according to the manner which preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If the patient is a child, then apply a fine cautery according to this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the manner of cauterizing in Melancholia.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholia is corrupted humours and thick phlegm, then cauterize it with the cauteries which I said in one having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholia is excess decliviating into melancholia, and the body of the patient is moist, then give him in drink what will purify his brain, according to what preceded in division: then shave the patient's head, and make thereafter a tortellam properly made from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and the patient sitting square be held from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is preferable with old sheep butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it over a fire with a temperate heating to the measure that a finger can tolerate when introduced into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of his head in a circle, and let it remain until it cools.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Make him take this remedy once every week until he is cured, with the remainder of his regimen being good.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making small punctures in it, and keep your hand with the cauterizer: let it smell.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this kind of cauterization moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place over it a cloth soaked in butter or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	¶ Concerning the method of cauterizing when water is flowing into the eye.
Caput XIII.	XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the source of the water in the eye is revealed to you by the signs, which I described in the division, then begin and make him take this remedy, together with what will cleanse his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep him from all humidity, and make him sit in a bath for several days of fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then order him to shave his head and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it twice on each temple with two cauterizations, if the onset of water descending into both eyes occurs simultaneously: or from one side, if the onset of water into one eye occurs: and cut all veins and arteries beneath the skin with the cauterizer: and let the cauterization be long in width across the temples: and beware of the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything from it, then cut it immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I pardon with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and cutting them, and precaution against the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when it is cauterized in the neck, under two bones, with two cauteries brought to a conclusion.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in ancient tears.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient and frequent, and are over the veins and arteries which are visible on the exterior of the head, it is verified that this is from excess of cold and phlegmatic humors: then cauterize with a cautery as I described at the beginning of the descent of water, in the middle of the head, and with two cauteries over the temples, and with two cauteries in the neck under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you find it necessary to add, then cauterize the same on the entire side of the eye, over the extremity of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in nasal fetor.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat it, with what we have said in division and not complete in the medication: then hasten, and give him infirmocochias in drink for three nights. Then shave his head, and cauterize it with a middle cautery, using an olive oil cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with a small cautery and two cauteries, over the eyebrows below the hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And beware of the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of cauterization of Clauilis.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in the treatment of palpebral mollification.
Caput XVI.	Head XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid is affected by an illness or humidity, then cauterize the eyelid with one cauterization, using this lunar cauterization.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above both eyebrows with two cauterizations in every part: and let them be distant from both temporal regions: and let the length of all cauterization be according to the lengths of the eyebrows: and do not bring your hand with the cauterization to the very end, but rather according to the quantity that is burnt on the second eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of cauterization according to this lunar cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing the eyelid when hair grows inward and irritates the eye.
Caput XVII.	Head XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	Cauterization in this case is according to two methods: either with fire: or with a burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	In cauterization with fire, first instruct the patient to remove their own hair, if it is from those that clean themselves, until they grow out and become equal in length.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If they irritate him at their point of growth, then bind his eyes with strips, so that they do not move, until they grow out.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When therefore they are born and equalized, then set the head of the sick person on your lap; subsequently make signs over the eyelids of his eyes with a medicated wax, the sign being in the shape of the figure of a myrtle leaf: and let the beginning of the sign be near the hair.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then apply a soaked cloth in egg white: or in psyllium mucilage over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then the cautery, the form of which is as follows.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize according to the figure you have marked in turns many times until the skin surface burns, which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf, entirely visible.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of your work's success is: that if you see the eyelid of the eye begin to contract, and hairs raise up near the puncture of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Raise then your hand: and let it go free for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place over it a cloth with butter until the eschar is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any hair returns within an hour and the eyelid softens, then cauterize that place again as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If however the hairs are on the lower part, then cauterize it until they rise to their natural place and are equalized so that the hairs do not irritate the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	¶ Regarding the method of cauterizing with burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	You should instruct the sick person to let their hair grow until it is prolonged and equalized.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from paper the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from known soap and from unabsorbed ash of each kind a weight of an ounce or nearly that: then rub these together with good crushing, and make them quickly, so that they do not cool.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then spread it out on the paper you made as the shape of a myrtle leaf, and place it over the eyelid of one eye, or both.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a cloth soaked in white wine: and the sick person's head be near your body.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your index finger on the medicine, and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you should move it whenever the sick person feels the bite of the medicine: for he finds its bite like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore the sick person continues to feel the bite of the medicine as he found it, then dismiss the medicine, and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When therefore the bite ceases, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then, if you see the eyelid lift, as it lifts during contraction with fire or with incision, it is well: and if not, then apply the medicine again to the same place, where the medicine does not impress itself nor darken, until your operation equals and contracts the eye.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then apply over it a mixture of cotum with butter until the burned skin is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with diaphinicon ointment or another, until it is cured.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And you must carefully guard against anything from the medicine falling into the eye during the operation.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eyelid softens after a few days and something from the hair fights against it in the eye, then apply the medicine to that place which softens from the eyelid, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is cured.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that human eyes vary in size and shape.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, according to this, consider it: and the way of the straight path is not hidden from him who has a study in this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	¶ Concerning the method of cauterizing in lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Head XVIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula, as we have said in the divisions of diseases, and your treatment is not见效: then, you must cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the patient to place his head in your lap, and hold his head with a servant between your hands in such a way that it is not moved nor shaken with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply Infused Cotum in a cloudy solution or in a mucilaginous psyllium preparation to his eye: then heat the Cauterium, whose form is as follows.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be a concavity, like the form of a bird's wing cane from one end, with which the Cautery is made: and if you wish it to penetrate to the other end, and if you wish it to go up so, try.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum valde.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosivam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod venit in capitulo suo.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of Cauterization for fistula, which some of the first ones said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Direct to the place of the fistula, and cut it: then place in the fissure camahan subtile, i.e., a fine cannula, whose form is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it a quantity of a drachm of melted lead, and hold your hand with a good Cannula for retention, and let the patient not move at all, so that the melted lead does not run or reach his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary to place over the patient's eye a cloth浸湿的蛋清，或者水。
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For the lead will burn the place of the fistula and heal it with a marvelous healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	For if the fistula is healed by what we have said from Cauterization and cure, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if it is not healed, then it is necessary to make a hole in the nose and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to where it will come to its proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in fissures of the Lips.
Caput XX.	Head XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Fissures called Pili often occur in the lips, and particularly in children's lips.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you treat these fissures, as we said in the division of diseases, and if the treatment is not effective, then prepare a small surgical cautery with fire, according to this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let its concavity be according to the subtlety of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place the ignited one quickly into the said cracks until the cauterization reaches the depth of the cracks.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with causticSubstance until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	¶ Concerning the Method of Cauterizing in Fistula of the Mouth.
Caput XXI.	Head XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs at the root of the tooth, in the palate, or at the roots of the teeth: it then produces pus and breaks open. Afterwards, it heals over, but the pus returns and forms a fistula. Then treat it, and do not apply any treatment inside it; then it is necessary to cauterize with fire according to the size that it takes in the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the ignited one into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand there until the heated iron reaches the depth and the end of it. Do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then treat it after that, using the method we have said until it is cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the pus is removed and it heals, that will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place and remove the root of the decayed tissue according to what comes to its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	¶ Concerning the Method of Cauterizing on Softened Gums and Teeth.
Caput XXII.	Head XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gums are softened due to humors, and the teeth are moved, and you treat it with medicines without success, then place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then apply cauterization with a form to be used after this, so that you place the Cannula over the tooth and insert the burning Cauterium quickly. And hold your hand slightly until the patient feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And raise your hand: then iterate the Cauterium several times, as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient fill his mouth with saline water and hold it for one moment: then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the moved tooth is fortified, and the softened gums are tightened, and the corrupted moisture is dried up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	¶ Concerning the method of cauterizing for toothache.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the toothache is due to cold, either the tooth itself is cold, or worms, and treatment with medicines does not help: then cauterization should be applied in two ways: either with butter, or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cauterization with butter is as follows: take aged butter, and boil it in a iron cup or a earthenware vessel.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take cotton and wrap it around the tip of the probe.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse it in the boiled butter: and place it quickly over the painful tooth. Hold it until it cools down, then repeat several times until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, immerse wool or cotton in cold butter, and place it over the painful tooth: and place over it a heated iron until the heat reaches the depth of the tooth's cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	Cauterization of it with fire is done so that you may direct the air tube or the iron tube.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And there shall be something of great thickness in its body so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the sick person's mouth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then apply the cautery with its sharp end: place it over the tooth: and hold your hand until the cautery cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will be relieved either on the same day or the next day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And the patient should fill his mouth with good butter at the spot of the cautery and hold it for one hour: then he should spit out the butter.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whichever end you wish, according to what is possible: and this is the form of the air tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	¶ Regarding the method of cauterizing in Strophulis.
Caput XXIIII.	Head XXIV.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When Strophulae are caused by phlegm and cold humors, and are not responding to medical treatments for digestion, and you wish to speed up their digestion, then use a concave cautery with its form as follows.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	It has two open ends, so that smoke may escape from the other end of the cautery: and place the heated one over the abscess once, and a second time if needed, until the heat reaches the depth of the abscess.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the abscess is small: then apply a cautery according to the size of the abscess.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then let it alone for three days, and apply a wet cloth soaked in butter over it until what the fire burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then treat it with tooth ointment until the form of the cannula is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in hoarseness and constriction of breathing.
Caput XXV.	Head XXV.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When the humors overcome the pulmonary canal, and especially when this is accompanied by a cold constitutional condition, then it is necessary to evacuate the patient first with medicinal purgatives.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it on the nodule at the root of the throat in the depressed place: and beware, do not apply the cautery to the throat or the skin unless there is something of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with another cautery at the junction of the neck at the last vertebra by burning it out: and let the cautery be hot iron according to the manner that preceded.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	¶ Concerning the manner of cauterizing in diseases of the lung and cough.
Caput XXVI.	Head XXVI.
