Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then place on the fire small olive oil cauters in great number: and blow upon them until they are thoroughly ignited.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one of them, whether small or large, according to the wound and place where the artery is cut, and place the cautery over the vein. After that, remove your finger quickly. And hold the cautery until the blood is separated.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	And if the blood is expelled as you raise your finger from the opening of the artery and you extinguish the cautery, then quickly take another cautery from those prepared on the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Therefore, do not cease to do this with one after another until the blood is separated.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And beware that you do not burn the nerve there, and other evils befall the weak.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, it is not possible to separate it; especially when the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, the extremities thereof are drawn together, and the blood is cut off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it may be ligatured with a strong ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or let medicines with the property of cutting off blood be placed upon it, and let it be bound with a suitable constrictive bandage.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Those who perform the amputation with a ligature and stricture using a bandage, or by placing combustible materials, do not provide it thoroughly, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If, however, such a thing happens to someone, and there is no physician or medicine at hand: then he should begin by placing his index finger over the opening of the vein itself, as we have described, and by stricking it strongly until the blood is blocked from the upper part of the wound, and above the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be removed until the blood is cooled and congealed, and thickened, and then cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile, let him consider what is needed from the cautery or from medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	¶ End of the First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	¶ On Incision, Puncture, and Phlebotomy in Wounds and Similar Cases.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already said in Chapter One that every disease wherein it is appropriate to use the cautery and burning medicine, and the occasions of its use, and its causes, and the instruments thereof, and the forms of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I have placed there chapters from the head to the foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter the same way: that which alleviates what is sought for the seeker.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin with this, you must learn, my sons, that which is here in this chapter regarding the fear that is mentioned in the first chapter on cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And because of this, it must be a warning more severe, for in the operation which is in this chapter, frequently evacuation with blood occurs, from which life stands at the opening of the vein, or incision over an abscess, or opening of the sinus, or healing of the wound, or removal of an arrow, or incision over a stone, and similar things: from all of which there arises trembling, fear, and death falls upon many of them.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, lest that which causes hesitation fall upon you, for sometimes such people with conditions of illness fall into your art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For among them are those who are angry with their illness, and death is light to him because of the intensity of what he finds from his illness and the length of his wickedness.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when the illness is from fear, which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And among them is one who gives his beneficence and enriches you with it, hoping for health, yet his illness is harmful.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore, you ought not to agree to him who comes to you from those whose method is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be greater than your cupidity and your rapacity.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume upon anything from it unless after certain knowledge, which is verified among you by a succession of events that leads to a worthy outcome.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use your skill in the cure of all your sick, prognosis, and direction concerning what is conducive to their health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	In that, indeed, you have assistance in the attainment of fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, my sons, with his wisdom, and may he not take away your direction and inspiration: for that is in his hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I have indeed arranged this Chapter by dividing it into sections, as it preceded in the Chapter on Cauterization from the neck to the feet: so that you may find what you seek and what you need from it.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	¶ On the cure of water that aggregates in children's heads.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this illness often occurs in children after birth: or when the midwife tightens the child's head without delicacy.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And it also occurs from a hidden cause which is unknown.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I have indeed not seen this illness in anyone other than children, and death came to every one of them whom I saw. Therefore, it seemed to me fitting to refrain from operating on it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I indeed saw a boy whose head was filled with water, and his head enlarged every day until he could not sit upon himself because of the greatness of his head: and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture aggregates either between the skin and the mouth: or beneath the bone above the jaw.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation in such a case, if there is moisture between the skin and the mouth, and the abscess is small, then it is necessary to make a single fissure in the middle of the head with a width of about two nodes, until the moisture flows.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the form of spatumils.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the moisture is more increased, and the abscess is larger, then place two fissures according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is beneath the bone, and the sign of it is that you see the openings of the skull widely separated from all sides: and when you compress it with your hand on the inside, water is pressed down and does not hide itself from you: then it is necessary to make three fissures in the middle of the head according to this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, extract all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then close the fissures with cloths and wool.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then embrocate it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then remove the bandage, and care for the wound with dressings and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not allow the head to be bound with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And food for the sick should be of such kind as is slightly moist, until the member is strengthened and cured.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another mode of incision is that you consider where the magnitude of the abscess and the collection of water are apparent.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes there is more in the occiput, or in the forehead, or on the right side, or on the left side.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore ascend with the incision where you see the abscess and collection of water, and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, lest you cut the artery, and a blood flow occurs, and the sick person dies from that flow along with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	¶ Concerning the Incision of Arteries Behind the Ears.
Caput II.	Head II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When catarrhs affect someone's eyes or chest, and the condition worsens without improvement from medical treatment, then incision of these two arteries is the more serious remedy.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore, when you wish to incise them, the sick person should shave their head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the area with a rough cloth to make the arteries apparent.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the sick person should tie their neck with any cloth they have.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the vein pulses.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the locations are those areas behind the ears that are depressed: and they are rarely hidden, except in some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with cauterization on both sides: and cut both with a scalpel on either side sharply, the incision arriving at the mouth: and let it be done through the breadth of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, introduce the scalpel under the artery, and cut it upwards with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be about two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut, blood issues forth with pulsating flow, which leaps to the interior in frequent jumps.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If the artery does not appear by touch, then one must measure from the ear the width of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with cauterization, and cut until you reach the mouth.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which ought to be drawn from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps you will draw more or less.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	Do this entire procedure according to the quantity which appears to you from the condition of the patient and the filling of his artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if anything remains up to the mouth, cut that away, so that a hot abscess does not occur: then ligate the wound with sutures from linen cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	¶ Concerning the extraction of arteries, which are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man that he has ancient hemicrania, or acute cataracts due to humid acrid mists, and the heat of seasons, or soda ancient and violent, and similar to these: and is treated with methods of medical cure, and does not yield to such: then in these diseases we have experienced extraction of arteries from the seasons, or cauterization of them, as we have narrated.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in extracting them is that the sick man shaves the hairs that are on the seasons, and directs himself to the apparent artery in the season.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	It is shown to you from his pulse, and rarely hides itself except in a few men or frenzy of cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it hides itself from you, then the sick man should tie his head with any of his clothes: then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or use vapor from hot water until it appears to you in a clear manifestation.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the spatumiles, which I formed for you before.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape the skin with it easily until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then thrust the hook into it, and draw it upward until you extract it from the skin, and make it emerge through the tunics beneath it from all sides.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If the artery is fine, then wrap it with the hook's extremity.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from it according to the length of its extremities when they are extended and contracted, so as not to cause a flow of blood.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not incised and not cut, the blood does not rise completely.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then evacuate from the blood ana 6 unciae, until .3.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large: then you must tie it in two places with a double, strong thread of silk or from alhoahod, so that putrefaction does not occur before the wound is consolidated and there is a flux of blood.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then incise the excess, which is between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do that at that hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery until the ends of it are incised, and let it remain in its place for the completion of the work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better to do this work, unless the patient has a fever, or a heated complexion.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Since the cautery is used to help dry up humidities.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better aid.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the extraction of the arteries to fill the place with old cloth, and to place there poultices properly made.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the poultice is removed, treat with dry medicines that cause flesh to grow, and with linens, until it is healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If meanwhile, while you are working, there is a flux of blood from the artery, then rush to cut it off with a cautery, or to fill the place with grease, and hold your hand tight until the blood is stopped.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If none of those are present for you, then place your finger over the spot, until the blood congeals.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And apply the embrocation to the place with water of great coldness, until the sharpness subsides and is drawn according to what is required.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And because it is lighter and easier for the extraction of the artery, cauterize the vein with this cauterium having two knives: let the sharpness of the two knives be similar to alum.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	Yet they have much less sharpness than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are as sharp as two knives, the cold will affect both of them quickly: and they do not strike the flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	For when there is a certain thickness in them, the heat of the fire is sustained in them, and the flesh is cut quickly: therefore this is better for every work, lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between the two knives be the width of a finger, after you mark two places with cauterization: and extinguish both fires greatly until they reach the surface and strike the vein in two places: so that it is extended between its extremities.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they do not become completely consolidated with this cauterization.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cauterization.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	¶ On the care for chronic sharp tears from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Head IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When there are frequent tears, and the course of their flow is from the veins that are above the skull externally: and medicine does not confer any cure upon them with medicines, and you see the face of the sick person already reddening, and he feels a movement on his forehead, as it were ants moving: and his eyes are attenuated, wet, so that now the hairs on them have been corroded by corrosion: and his eyelids are heated from the acuteness of the tears: then in their cure, the ancients required this operation, and they called it a cure with the Knife.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And you shall order the sick person to shave the hair that is on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions on the forehead at equal distances according to the length of the forehead: and let the length of each incision be about two fingers wide. One incision should be equidistant from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, the second slightly according to the length between the eyebrows, and the third from the other side: and take care to avoid cutting the arteries that are on both sides: and extend your hand away from the continuity of the lower jaws, and let the length of every incision be three finger-widths. Have prepared for you a slice of sponge or many dried cloths with which you may dry the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert two sharp-pointed probes, the form of which follows shortly.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision which is on the side of the temple, to the second incision: and scrape off with it the entire skin which is between the two incisions, together with the sebaceous matter that is above the mouth.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do the same from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then withdraw this spatula, and introduce into the first incision again another instrument, which is called the sharp knife, gently from one side, not sharply from the other.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side toward the flesh attached with skin, and its blunt side toward the mouth: and thrust it until it reaches the middle fissure: and cut with it all vessels that descend from the head to the eyes: provided that the incision is continued until that which appears from the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do this in the middle fissure until it reaches the other fissure.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after an equal quantity of blood runs out, express the places from the fragments of coagulated blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place lint from old cloth into all the fissures, and place little sponges soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar over them.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see that no hot abscess occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day, loosen the ligature, and administer a large infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with basilicon ointment and other ointments used for wounds until it is healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	¶ Concerning the care of acute lachrymal and catarrhal conditions affecting the eyes from internal parts of the head.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When acute, severe, and frequent catarrhs occur to someone, and you see his eyes thin, small, and already weakened in their appearance: and the eyelids are ulcerated, and hair falls from them, and there is a sharp, painful pain deep in the head, accompanied by sneezing: then take from these occurrences what those materials and catarrhs do not come, unless from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And better treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And you should shave the patient's forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make one incision in the fissure on the middle of the forehead, or on the other slightly by breadth, and begin with the incision from the left side to the right side: let the cut extend to the mouth: and keep your hand away from the temporal bones, which move near chewing: until when the mouth is uncovered: and dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the incision with an old probe, or with linen forceps.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then suture from above with stitches: and soak the needles in wine and oil, so that no hot abscess occurs.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you dissolve that and see that the hot abscess is diminishing, then you should foment the mouth until flesh begins to grow there.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then care for it with an exsiccative regimen that causes flesh to grow: as, for example, if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony: prepare an ointment from these, and apply it to the growth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	¶ Concerning the care of what falls into the Ear.
Caput VI.	Head VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the ear is one of four species: either a mineral stone, or similar to a stone, such as iron and glass: or it is from a plant, such as beans and peas: or it is a fluid substance, such as water and vinegar and things similar to them: or some animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore a stone or kind of stone that does not grow in the ear falls into the ear, expose the ear to the sun: if therefore you see the stone, then drop something from violet oil or sesame oil into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer the extraction of it, and make him sneeze when you place [the remedy] in, and plug the nostrils at the approach of sneezing. After you put fragments from cloths or wool in the surroundings of the ear, and extend the ear向上.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	For it often emerges with this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If it does not emerge, then administer the extraction with Gesti, i.e.,细密甘草:其形状是这样的。
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If it emerges with Gesti, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer the extraction with a fine hook of few doublings.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If it does not emerge through that, then make a tube of metal, and introduce the end of the tube into the ear canal much, and plug what is in the surroundings of the tube with softened wax and oil, so that there is no passage except through the tube: then extract it with your strong suction.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For it often emerges with what we have described.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If it does not emerge this way, then take from helkalimbat or from uisco, i.e., prepared gluten with which birds are caught, a small quantity: and place it at the end of the radius after you envelop it with a cloth properly placed: then introduce it into the ear canal with ease, after you dry the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If therefore it does not emerge with all that we have narrated, then hasten to incise before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the measure of the incision is that the phlebotomist should first bleed the weak in the cephalic region: and draw from him blood according to the measure of his strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the patient sit between your hands, and turn his ear upward, and make a small incision at the root of the ear beside the fat in a depressed place: and let the incision be crescent-shaped until you reach the stone; then remove it along with whatever is possible for you with your instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then attend to the incision according to your hour with speed and care until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If what falls into the ear is from one of those grains that grow and swell: then administer its extraction.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not yield to you for removal, then take a thin spoon-like instrument, fine and according to this form.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the excision of that kind from the grains which fall into the ear, and do not do this when you think that grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear until you place many fragments thereof: then remove them with forceps, or with a fine hook, or with suction, as we have said, for its extraction should be facilitated.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	In water that enters the ear, the patient should use a sneeze when first placed there: and now it has filled his ear with a bit of old decoction: and he is lying on that ear where the water is.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it emerges through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many small stones, according to the length of a finger, thin and soft, and heat them slightly with fire, and let the patient take one from those and insert it into the hole in his ear: and let one stone fall from his foot on that side, and strike it with another stone on the stone that is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore do not cease with the stone and the stone until all the water emerges.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now water is emerging such that you may take one end of a piece of cotton or a splint and insert it into the ear: and ignite the other end with fire until most of it burns.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then iterate with another splint, and do this many times until all the water emerges: and extract it using a tube according to what was previously mentioned on the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In the extraction of an animal entering there, if it is a small creature such as a louse or similar, care for it as I said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is a large creature, which is apparent by sense: then administer its extraction with forceps and hooks: and this is easier than all that is held within the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	In the extraction of a worm generated in the ear, when you treat it as we said in the division and in the discussion of distillations, and if your treatment does not见效： then you should examine the ear in the sunlight.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore something from the worms is apparent there, then extract it with forceps or with thin hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If, however, nothing appears there, then take a cannula, whose form is thus, narrow below, wide above: and introduce the fine end according to the quantity which the sick person tolerates: then suck with a strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Perform this many times until all the worms emerge.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If, however, they do not obey you to go out, then surround the wound with the point of a knife as I said on the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not emerge with what we have said: then administer the distillations which the ancients used for the destruction of worms, and you will find this in the treatise on distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your application be with the oil and medicines you pour into the ear using this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, make it from silver or bronze, narrow below with a small hole, and wide above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let it be such that the part of the cannula that is pressed, which is in its concavity, be made from bronze off-centered.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a ray, and wrap it at the end with cotton in a suitable winding: then project oil, or juice, or what you wish from these medicines into the cannula: and let it be in the ear: then introduce the ray with the cotton above, and express it with your hand using gentle compression until the oil is pushed into the concavity of the ear, and the sick person feels it internally: and that which is poured into the ear may now be heated slightly with fire: and beware lest what is distilled into it be very cold: for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the care of complications of the ear.
Caput VII.	Head VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes infants emerge from their mothers' wombs unperforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it has also happened to some individuals that perforation of the ear occurred either through a wound or as flesh growing there.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this perforation sometimes occurs in the deep part of the ear canal, which does not affect hearing: and sometimes it happens to the outer part of the ear canal only, and affects that hearing.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which occurs in the deep part of the ear and which the appearance does not reveal is in many cases difficult to cure.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And for that which affects hearing, you should place the ear of the patient in the sun and examine it: then if you see a perforation appearing, open it with a probe that is very fine, whose shape is as follows—the end has a small width and one part is sharp, while the rest of the probe has two gentle sides so as not to damage the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If the perforation is caused by flesh growing in the ear canal, then hold it with a fine forceps and cut it with vigorous ease until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the perforation is in the deep part of the ear, then take a fine, gentle probe and heat it slightly with fire: then insert it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If therefore you sense the perforation along with the great hearing loss that the patient has, try to open it with ease: and beware, lest you injure the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place a wick in the ear according to the width of the opening, which you have enclosed in Egyptian ointment: do this for several days until you are assured of the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take a wick, and infuse it in rosewater, and powder over it ground zegi, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see the ear already suppurating: then it is necessary to remove the wick, and let it be with another wick which you enclose in cerate made with rose oil until the hot abscess settles: then care for it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If, however, there is a bleeding: then submerge a sponge or cloth in cold water and place it over the ear: and continue with the remaining treatment which stops the flow of blood as described in the treatise on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	¶ Concerning the care of eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Head VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These eyelid ailments (Althelil) sometimes are humid and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore, you should hold them with forceps or with forceps, and incise them from their roots with a spatula.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place ground zegi over the affected areas.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If, however, blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a thin lens-shaped cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And cauterizing them is better after incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For they often return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned, and they do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	¶ Concerning the Care of Granulations of the Eyelids.
Caput IX.	Head IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Often something occurs on the eyelids that is similar to granules in its strength and hardness, and for this reason it is called granulation: it is an aggregation of thick moisture on the upper eyelid and the lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Therefore, the operation on them is this: consider whether the granulation is spreading from something apparent on the eyelid and moving to all parts, and its nature is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Make therefore an incision over it lengthwise.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape it off from all sides with ease until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a forceps, and cut it out.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	If the excision of it is not prepared for you, so that you can cut it out only after you penetrate the eyelid with a slight incision, then it may harm the patient in some way.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the incision is large, then suture it and care for it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For ointment restores it and causes it to heal.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if a stone is turned inward toward the inner ear surface, then turn back the eyelid, and hang the stone with a hook: besides which you need an incision, and press it from every part.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	And if the eyelid is drawn out by an incision, it will not harm that in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision with the stone and salted water: and take care of the area as it heals until the sick person is cured.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	¶ Concerning the care of eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is the fat that forms in the upper eyelid tissues: and it happens most frequently with children. This fat burdens their eyes, and causes them to have cataracts in the mornings, and they cannot look at the sun's light because the tears rush to their eyes. Because of this, you see them always lying on their faces and sleeping on them, and their eyelids beneath their eyebrows are wet, which is now covered by inflammation: and the appearance of Axirnath is evident to the eye, and when you press the area with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of its treatment is that the sick person places his head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth, and prepare lint on it, and make from that lint a circle according to the size of the Axirnath around all parts.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place it over the affected area, and press it with your fingers from all sides, so that the Axirnath collects in the center of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that humidity with a probe incident and note the fissures running laterally, and let not that larger fissure be which is made in phlebotomy in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or you must find the skin wholly until you reach Axirnath, for Axirnath proceeds from the fissure according to the form of a fragment of white fat.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Therefore, extract it with a cloth which you have moistened between your fingers and bring it to the exterior: and you turn your hand to the right and left until it is dispersed: and beware, lest you add to the fissure, so that you do not reach with the probe the eye and injure it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If, however, Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the fissure, you must add to the fissure a little with facility until Axirnath proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Therefore, extract it as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Therefore, immerse the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them over the area, and bind it with wicks.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are some who grind salt and place it in the depression of the fissure, so that what remained from that humidity may liquefy.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Therefore, take care of it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If, however, an热乎的脓肿出现在该处，那么用镇热的药膏护理它，直到痊愈。
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	¶ Concerning the treatment of Ataxmira of the eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes softened and causes wrinkling as it should not.
Caput XI.	Head XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When hairs grow on the eyelids in addition to the natural course of hair and become thickened: then they harm the eye, and cause diseases such as frequent tears, softening of the eyelids, and cloudiness, until it leads to the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And Ataxmir's eye is cured according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cauterization with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, as prescribed in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or Ataxmir is cured by incision and suturing.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or with a catheter, as I will say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You must place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it turns, it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if it does not turn, insert the needle into that part which contains the thread from the lower part of the eyelid, and let the needle penetrate with the thread from above, and be close to the hairs, that is, near the margin of the eyelid where the hairs grow. Then pull the thread up with the eyelid and turn it with a pin.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then puncture the inner part of the eyelid under the additional hairs with a spatula gradually moving from the larger lacrimal gland to the smaller one.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then extract the thread, and place a small lint of cotton or cloth under the eyelid: then mark the eyelid with wax, which should be like the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	True enough, the figure must be made according to the size and elevation of the eyelid: for this varies among people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For there are those who require that a large quantity be incised from the eyelid, according to the amount that is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then, using the spatula, cut between the two lines you have marked, and begin from the larger lacrimal gland to the smaller one, and let the incision be near the natural eyelashes, as is the thickness of a radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the hook into one of the angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then strip away the entire layer.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then sew the two lips together with a needle and fine wool thread. Dry the blood, and make what flows from the threads above the two eyebrows adhere, along with some viscous substances if you wish to do so: if not, you need not worry about it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then remove the stitches and thread until three days or four have passed: then care for it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without stitches and care for it along with what dries and constricts it.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid will be elevated at the sealing of the wound and its sewing: but it will be better in the future.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of treating Ataxmir the ancients have taught.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	True indeed is concern for the patient, and this is from good practice, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another method is for Ataxmir as well: and it is that you mark a figure on the eyelid, which should be like the shape of a myrtle leaf, as we have described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then lift the eyelid with three separated or aggregated hooks, according to the following shape, and then cut away what is superfluous with small pincers, according to this form, with equality in the incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If, however, it is not possible for you to hold the hook and it is not equal: then take a needle with thread and introduce it into the middle of the figure. And introduce another thread near the larger lacrimal duct, and another thread near the smaller lacrimal duct. Hold the threads between your fingers with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then lift your hand with an equal lifting motion, and lift the skin upon which the mark is made, as we have described.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then suture the two edges of the wound together: and care for it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If, however, an abscess occurs at your incision or fissure, treat the abscess with a cautery and similar substances from soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens that the eyelashes also turn inward.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore, you should use what we have said about the incision, but suturing is more artificial for both.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	Of the care of Ataxmires with canes.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is, as the eyelid is turned and the fissure inside is incised, as I have narrated.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two canes or two thin sticks, whose length be according to the length of the eyelid, and their width be less than the width of a spasmus: and you have already cut at the extremities from both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then join both with a fine needle to what surplus remains from the eyelid, and tightly tie the two canes from both sides with a strong ligature, and remove it after a few days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin tightened will die, and become darkened and putrefied until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If therefore it is delayed, then cut it with pincers.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore it is consolidated, lift the eyelid: and the hairs will not irritate.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of the two canes, which you should make according to this shape and size in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	Of the removal of irritating hairs from the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	Head XII.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation is this: take a fine needle and insert a thread of fine, soft silk into it.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then join its ends together, and tie them with a very fine knot: and let the length of the threads be one hand's breadth.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then compose another fine thread under it in brief, and knot the ends thereof if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then the patient should place his head in your lap, and let it be near the sun to determine the operation: for it is a subtle or minor operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the awl with the linen thread into the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly, until you pull it out from above the natural hair.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the hair until it is above the linen thread: and insert that hair into the linen thread: if there is one, or two, or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand with it until the hair comes out with the linen thread from the eyelid along with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If, however, the linen thread is pulled out and no hair comes out with it: pull the linen thread to the inside, using the thread that you inserted into it, until the linen thread comes out from the upper opening, and you see it with your eye: then you pull the linen thread and the thread that you composed in it, and extract both, and close the eye: and leave it closed for two or three days until the hair adheres to its place and grows above the same flesh.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either associate it with a longer hair from the natural hairs, and it will be pulled out with it: or leave it alone until it lengthens over time, and then pull it out.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	¶ Concerning the care of Alxatrati which occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this happens to the eye according to Alxatrati, it is called Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this according to Alxatrati is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Therefore, it is accidental through the consolidation of a wound, or a section, or a cautery, and similar conditions.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of treatment is this: you must find that consolidation, and separate its margins, and place something licit from linen between them, and bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And you must not use things that dry and constrict in its treatment. For if you do that, it becomes worse than it was according to Alxatrati: rather, use things that soften, such as hay, and a compress with water in which althea has been boiled, flaxseed, and dyaquilon ointment, melted with some oil. Wrap something licit around it and care for it accordingly.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And your store of treatment is to use every means possible so that it does not consolidate according to the original form.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation that we have described is nothing more than a correction of Alxatrati so that it does not return to the original form of the place.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	¶ Concerning the treatment of Alxatrati that occurs in the lower eyelid, which is a wrinkling or contraction upwards to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This according to Alxatrati that occurs below is truly called Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And it is accidental, arising from a wound, or crack, or cautery, and things similar to these.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way of operation therein is, that you take a needle with a double thread, and dye it in flesh, and make it penetrate from the left lacrimal to the right lacrimal until the thread reaches the two extremities of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh upwards with a needle, and cut it with a broad spatula.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the shape of the eyelid returns as it should, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if it does not return to its shape as it should, take a needle, place it in the crack, and turn with it the eyelid: and make two cracks on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two cracks be from the two angles of the incision until they meet and form an angle: until they come together, let this shape be formed, and it is the letter lambda in Greek.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh in the amount of its acute lower side, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then unite the separated parts: suture them with wool thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we have said about medicaments that soften and are harmless until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if Alxatrati occurs from a crack, and suture, or cautery: then you must make a flat crack beneath the eyelashes, even according to what preceded.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with a ligature, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the summary of Alxatrati's care, whether above or below, is that the operation should run through it, according to how it is prepared from the form of Alxatrati.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For it is of many diverse forms. And the skilled artisan prepares the instrument in any possible way until it returns to or approaches the natural form, and the patient himself, according to what is appropriate for him from the operation and instruments in many dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	On the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva or cornea.
Caput XV.	Head XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this consolidation occurs in many people, such that the upper eyelid fuses with the whitish part of the eye, and thereby prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore, you must introduce the extremity of the needle under the eyelid and lift it upwards: or extend it with a hook: then incise the adhesion with a thin spatula, which should not be sharp but slightly obtuse: so that the patient is not disturbed during the operation, and the spatula be removed without damaging the eye with its sharpness: and your incision should be such that you dissolve the adhesion easily until when the eyelid returns to its natural form and the entire adhesion is healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour saline water into the eye and wash it with water: or distill into it from a sieve made from zinc dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a thread: and place over the eye wool steeped in a mixture of alum: and after three days use the syringe, and with catgut sutures until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	¶ Incision of the nail and prominence of tear-carving flesh.
Caput XVI.	Head XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the nail is in two modes.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is nervous and is similar to a hard, fine strand.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous and is similar to white moisture that when touched by iron, or you try to grasp it with a hook, it breaks off and the hook does not stick in it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And neither type begins unless from the larger tear duct, gradually flowing until it covers the vision and obstructs both the light and the movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of incising it is this: the sick person should place his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then gather the nail with a hook of few doublings and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle and insert a thread from the hairs of a horse, cow, or goat. Let it be strong and double the end of the needle slightly, and fix it in the middle of the nail. Pierce it with the needle and ligate the nail with the thread, extending it upwards. Remove the outer layer of hair of the nail that follows the pupil as if you were sewing it with the hair until its root.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remainder at the root of the lacrimal gland with a sharp spoon or with small forceps: and let the natural lacrimal flesh be removed, so that there does not occur an incessant flow of tears from incision of it.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the nail is extended with a single hook: or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then it is scraped with a gentle spoon, whose form is as follows.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And be careful that the spoon does not touch the corneal tunic, and there is no rupture therein, and the pupil is perforated.
