Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that there are many incisors and files suitable for cutting these bones, according to the position of the bones, their preparation, their thickness, their fineness, their size, their thinness, their hardness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore, you must prepare an instrument suitable for every species of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations indicate to you the species of instrument you need when you have long study and preparation.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of the methods of this art is a testimony to the degrees of illness: for then you will find by yourself what is suitable from the instruments for every illness.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments which you should place as examples on which you will cut, and the test you will use to verify others.
Forma Serrae.	Form of the Saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Form of Another Saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of the Other Saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of the Other Saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the Saw is depicted out of place.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let the upper arc be made of iron, its sharpness from iron: and the handle thereof of boxwood, and let it be pyramidal, out of place.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	Form of the Joining of the Razor.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this Razor be according to the form of the head of a stellar hammer: and its points be according to the form of the teeth of elischetfegi.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it must fit only when the heads of the joining parts are rubbed against it when they are damaged, or the large and wide mouth.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Form of the Larger Razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	Form of the Medium Razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	Form of the Wide Razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Form of the Razor with a Concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Form of the Other Thin Razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Form of the Razor with Curved Ends.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Form of the Small, Thin Razor.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Form of the Razor with Which Bones Are Shaved.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Forma etiam rasorii magni.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to a Radius, and the extremity is like a Saw: exhibited in many places from the reason of the bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The form of the razor is suitable to the reason thereof that it is perforated from the bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	The extremity is triangular, and its ends are sharp.
Fit ex Indi.	It is made from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly, it is necessary that all which we have said be made from razors, incisors, and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On the incision of extremities and the osteotomy.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter VIIIIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	Extremities putrefy either from an external cause or an internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have treated that corruption with medical remedies and the cure does not take effect, and you see the corruption extending to the limb where nothing checks its progress, then it is necessary to cut that limb away until where the corruption reaches, so that the patient may escape death or a malady greater than the defect of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this happens is when the limb darkens until it is thought to be putrid; when fire burns it or it putrifies after discoloration; when that corruption is cut away until what follows the limb, and it spreads throughout the entire body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, when making the incision of that limb, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from the strike of some venomous creatures: such as the marine scorpion, viper, or rattlesnake, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore decay or injury is in the extremity of the finger, then cut off the finger, and do not leave space for the decay, so that it may advance to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut it off from the root of the finger, and do not leave space for the decay, until it reaches the brachial artery.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades there, then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If the decay passes through and you see it about the elbow: then death is near the patient.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And administering beyond that in treatment is the quantity of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do for the foot, when decay invades the finger, then cut it off at one of the joints: and if it reaches the ankle of the foot, then cut off the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If it has ascended to the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If the decay has already reached above the knee, then there is no remedy for it except to dismiss it and leave the patient to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the proper way to cut the limb or saw through it is to bind the ligament below the part you wish to cut: and bind another ligament above the site.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let the attendant extend one ligament below: and let him extend another ligament above.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments using a wide spatula, until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it should be cut or ligated.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And you should place linen cloth from all sides, and the serrated edge should not touch the healthy spot: and it happens that an additional infected wound arises.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If, however, there is an internal flow of blood while operating, then cauterize the place quickly: or place some blood-absorbing powders over it.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then ligate the wounded limb with an appropriate ligature, and care for it until it is healed.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happens to a man in his foot, this being the same as what I tell you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	Which is because a blackening occurs in his foot due to a burning similar to fire combustion. And that corruption first affects his toe until it began to involve the entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore, the man treated himself after he saw the corruption set in with his impairment, which he found from the pain and burning he experienced: and it affected him at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption occurred in his index finger.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	Therefore, he came to me, and I attempted to cure the discharge with what I applied to his hand after cleansing his body: but the discharge did not subside, and it began to affect another finger: until the corruption set in his entire hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He therefore called upon me to cut his hand: and I refused, hoping for a reflection of that surplus over the incision: and I feared even death beside him at the cutting of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the man's strength was above his fall.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Therefore, after he had given up on me, he returned to his own land: and he came back to me because he was in a hurry, and cut off his whole hand: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I have not related this narrative except as an aid to that which falls under the category of this illness: and as a signification by which it may be indicated, and according to which action should be taken.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	¶ Concerning the care of Sinuses, and the quality of clistherization with medicines.
Caput XC.	Head XC.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in certain fleshy members and the space of the abscess is prolonged until a collection of sanious material is formed: then it breaks or is punctured, and what is within it flows out through the sanious discharge, leaving behind a vacuous place like a vessel: and the skin above it is as a thin cloth: and it does not reach its ultimate corruption, nor does it impress itself on the bone, nor in the nerve, nor in the ligament: it deserves to be named a Sinus: and it is not called a Fistula: yet if the space of it is prolonged until corruption impresses itself upon one of these members, then it is called a Fistula or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the care of it is to cut that skin entirely away as it is turned back: and especially when it is thin like a cloth: and you are confident that it does not adhere to the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If you hope that it will adhere to the skin, and no such ultimate corruption follows from it: and if there is thickness in the skin from flesh, then treat it with a clister, and see to it for the sake of the Sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	If it is large, and the pus that is emitted from it has a foul odor, then prepare the clister with Egyptian medicine, which consists of vinegar, oil, and zingiber, taking equal parts, mix them in a vessel, and boil them over fire until the medicine turns red: and let it become thick like honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take what you need from it: and dissolve it with water and honey, and use it to treat the Sinus with a clister. Tighten its opening, and let the medicine remain therein for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression: do this for several days until the Sinus is cleansed and the odor is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when clistered with ash water, if this medicine is not at hand: take the ashes of vine branches, or ashes from oak wood, and pour water over them.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then keep it there and clister with it until you are confident that the Sinus has been thoroughly cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient cannot tolerate the Egyptian medicine or ash water, then use it with water and honey, to which some zingiber powder has already been added.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or clister with it mixed with honey and wine, for honey has the property of cleansing and washing: and wine makes it adhere to the Sinus, especially when there is an excess of astringency and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you do this several times, and you are confident that the sinus corruption is now removed: then the enema itself with what it makes to be born flesh in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And take from the paste dyafinicon: and dissolve it with rose oil, and astringent wine: or the enema itself with certain medicines and other ointments, of which properties I have written in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	And if the sinus orifice is strict, into which the enema cannula does not fit: then widen it slightly with a knife: or place therein a lintel wrap immersed in Egyptian ointment or basilicon ointment until it is widened.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly, if the orifice is even wide, then suture its edges together: and leave in it a quantity into which the enema can enter without additional insertion.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly, if the orifice from which pus flows is elevated higher up: then dry it out in a lower spot that is within it, so that the pus may flow down from there: for when pus is constricted in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from being generated therein.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	And if it is not possible for you to dry the sinus lower down as you wish: then try to prepare the member with a preparation that will allow the pus to flow from there easily according to how it is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try to prevent anything from being retained there entirely from the pus: and take consolidating medicines that are placed over the mark, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And apply them to a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such quantity that communication of the entire sinus may be made.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps directly into the sinus orifice to make a孔隙，稍微扩大 sinus 或ifice.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend another cloth with gentle ointment over the first, according to the size of the aperture: and place it far from the sinus orifice, so that the discharge may be alleviated from there: and do not remove the large cloth unless after some days singly.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	That which is over the sinus orifice, you will remove at every hour, so that what accumulates there from pus may exit: and by this you will know whether what flows from it is much or little, whether digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And consider again the place of the sinus itself, whether the lord feels pain therein, or there is no pain therein, and whether there is an abscess, or there is no abscess.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment is thus extended, and you see the material that exits over the sinus orifice, then know that the sinus now adheres, or approaches adherence: therefore dissolve it in the morning, or on the third day. And when you dissolve the wound, then replace another cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If however a subtle poison exits from the sinus after a long interval, then do not despair of its adherence, for its healing is approaching, for there are people who delay the growth of flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act contrary to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If however pus undigested exits from the sinus after many days, then know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If therefore the adhesion of the Sinus is delayed and its course prolonged, then for the drying of medicines, but let the doctors do it so that they are medicines in their substance moist and in their virtue dry: as ointment diafinicon, when added to it excess is added from zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the very last stage of its cure, it is that you take the ointment diafinicon and dissolve it with rose oil, and let it be spread over old wine equal in its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then prepare it with it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now it does the same as this action when you do not have diafinicon ointment at hand, honey, when you cook it until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and aloes, and frankincense: rub them all together, and powder it over honey while it is on fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then spread it over the cloth, and bind it over the sinus: and with the honey you have cooked until it thickened, powder the preparation, and place it over the cloth, and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes aristolochia longa, and roots of celestial lily, and lily: and herb flour, and centaury, are administered in that.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them in their simple form or combined, rub them, and sieve them: and powder them over the honey as I have described, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If therefore the course of the Sinus is prolonged and it is not cured by this treatment: then know that there is corruption deep within it. Or it has already made an impression in the bones, or in the other hard parts, or in the ligaments: then cure it with the treatment for fistulas, according to what was previously stated.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	On the care of a carbuncle and a worn nail, and the incision of an added finger, and its division.
Caput XCI.	Chapter XCII.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	A carbuncle is an abscess that arises under the nail of the thumb of the hand or the foot, and perhaps it may arise in other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When therefore it is prolonged and neglected and becomes abscessed with a warm abscess: or it decays and emits pus until it eats into the root of the nail: and perhaps it corrupts the whole nail, and perhaps corruption reaches the bone until there is an offensive odor: and the end of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When therefore you treat it, as we said in the division, and your treatment does not converge on it: then you must incise with a knife all the excess that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For the cautery is very useful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If however the bone is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the additions of the nail have already compressed the flesh inward and are beginning to sting it and hurt it: then you must place a fine radium under an angle of the nail that stings the flesh, and drive it upward. And cut the flesh with facility, and place over what remains of the flesh from the burning medicines, corroding ones, until all of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If corruption has already begun in the mouth, then you must cut that mouth and remove it; for it is never cured while腐败已经蔓延到口腔中，那么必须切割该部位并移除它；否则在口腔中有腐败存在的情况下，它永远无法治愈。
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see corruption and decay advancing to the finger, then cut it off at one joint, according to what has been previously mentioned.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is cured.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If there happens to be nail wear or injury, and severe pain occurs, then it is necessary to bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp transverse slice of Spatula.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And beware that the incision does not reach the flesh which is beneath the nail, for you will cause severe pain to the patient, and this will be a cause for additional flesh to grow in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the area with what alleviates pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	A finger added that grows in some people's hands may be wholly fleshy: and in some of them, there may be bones, and a nail may be present: in some cases, it grows at the root of the joint, or its growth is in certain joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	That which grows at the joints of the finger does not move, and that which grows near the joint of the finger may move.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, the one that is fleshy among them is easy to cut.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, to cut it there at its root with Spatumi lato.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	Its origin being at the root of the joint is difficult to cure.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, avoid cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In that which is born at the end of the digit near the last nodes, then you must cut the flesh thereof with a round incision through to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then cut the bone with one of those saws fitting to that.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Consolidation which occurs between the digits is often due either to the man's nature, that is, it is born with him, or from the healing of a wound, or from burning by fire, and similar causes.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, you must cut away that consolidation until the digits return to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them licinia or wet cloths in rose oil: so that they do not consolidate quickly, and separate them. Alternatively, place between them a thin lead lamina until the area consolidates as required.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly, if consolidation occurs between some digits and the palm, then dry that consolidation, as it is prepared and fits the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	¶ Incision for Vitiæ.
Caput XCII.	Head XCII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Vitiæ are Veins involuted, thick, full of excess melancholic matter which affect many parts of the body: and they chiefly issue from the legs, especially from the legs of those who walk much, work, or carry things.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, you should administer the extraction of the body from black bile several times with a strong extraction.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then phlebotomize the patient and give him basilic.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	Cure of these with iron is according to two modes.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	Their vein is to be punctured, and black blood is to be extracted.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And another mode is to elevate the vein and extract all of it.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The section of it is according to this mode.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Apply embrocation to the thigh first with hot water much until the thick and foul blood is resolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the thigh of the sick person from the upper part of the hip, down to the lower part of the knee with a band.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry the vein in one, or two, or three places with a wide cut.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then elevate it, that is, extract the blood with your hand from the lower part of the thigh up to the top. From the upper part, you should phlebotomize the sick person first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the nail with something downward until an amount of blood sufficient and tolerable by the patient's strength emerges.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then ligate it: and order him to abstain from foods generating black bile. And repeat the evacuation and phlebotomy when the veins are full, and this will harm the sick person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of it is according to this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Radify the weak thigh, if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then insert it into the bath: or immerse the thigh in embrocation with hot water until it becomes ruddy and the veins swell: or it may be exercised vigorously if a bath is not available until the limb warms up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin along the length of the vein incision: or at its end near the knee, or at the lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with forceps and scrape the vein from all sides until it becomes apparent to the touch: and at its appearance, you will see it turn ruddy toward black.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it therefore exits the skin, you will see it white as if it were a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert the Radium under it, until when it is elevated and exits the skin: suspend it with a blind forceps gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry the other incision near that incision with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein until it becomes apparent.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then elevate it with the Radium as you did before, and suspend it with another forceps as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry the other incision, or more incisions if needed for that case.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate it, and cut the last incision near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then extract it to the section which is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do that until you extract it from the section which is above, or all higher sections, until it emerges entirely; then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not yield to you in extraction and elevation, then introduce a needle with a strong double thread, ligate it, and extract it. Or introduce a radium beneath it, and turn your hand in all directions until it emerges.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be careful, lest you cut through it.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut through, it will be difficult for you to elevate it greatly, and it will enter the weak part causing harm.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have extracted it entirely, then place over the wound a piece of wool soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil, and care for it until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vine (vein) is contracted, having a twisting nature with winding and involuted parts, and it is not as we said according to its straightness, then you must find over it through all parts of its twisting nature and the places of its winding.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with forceps until you elevate it entirely. And be careful at the section above it not to cut the vein or make a wound, for it will be difficult for you to elevate or extract it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore, preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.
Forma Vncini caeci.	Forma Vncini caeci.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It does not have the sharpness of the Vincis, nor is it pointed at the extremity so as not to wound the vein: and it is of great flexibility, soft: for if it were fine, it would cut the vein with its subtlety: rather its excessive thickness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the Extraction of the Crural Vein.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter XCIII.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in warm lands, such as Alizegi, and the land of the Arabs, and in dry, warm, tender lands, that is, in which no grass nor tree is born.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from putrefaction that occurs beneath the skin, just as snakes and ascaris worms arise within the body, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the onset of the outcome of this vein is inflammation in the leg that occurs suddenly.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the area blisters.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to emerge from that blistered area, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore the extremity of the vein becomes apparent, then it is necessary to wrap a fragment of lead, whose weight is from one to two drachms, around it and mark the vein: and let the lead hang from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever therefore something emerges from it to the exterior, wrap that in lead and mark it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it is prolonged much, then cut the part thereof, and wrap the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it to the root until it wholly emerges.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it, it contracts and enters the flesh: and it causes an abscess, corruption, and a bad ulcer to occur.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore, it must be handled gently and extracted gradually until it emerges from its last part, and nothing of it remains in the body: and in some persons this vein emerges, which is five palms and ten [fingers] in length.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And it has now reached me, because it emerged from the man at twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If it happens to you in the hour of your medication: then introduce a probe into its opening, and puncture it with a long hole, together with the body, until all that is in it from the matter is evacuated: and administer corruption of the place with medicinal treatments for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then treat it with the cure for abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, particularly when it appears at the ankle joint or on the foot itself: and it encounters many openings, and a branch emerges from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore, treat it as we have said in the division, and along with what was previously mentioned.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	¶ Concerning the section on worms generated under the skin, and it is called Bovine Illness.
Caput XCIIII.	Head XCIV.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This Illness is named in certain lands among us as the Bull Illness: for this reason, because it often happens to bulls, and is a small worm that is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it goes throughout the entire body, ascending and descending: and it is perceived by touch through its movement from member to member, until it ruptures somewhere on the skin and exits.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the corruption of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just as worms and snakes, that is, earthworms and ascarids, occur in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared because of its malice.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it goes throughout the body and rises to the head and reaches a place, then perhaps it opens there, exits, and destroys the eye: and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When therefore you wish to cure it and extract it, then this can be done only through its movement and the perception of it by touch.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, you must tie what is above it and what is below it with a strong constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry it above, and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it is deep in the flesh and you do not find it, then place a cautery with fire over the spot until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than what is feared is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If you see it has already reached the head near the eye, then tighten above it a good indentation.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry it over and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And the patient should use the purification of his body with medicines that dissolve putrid and bad fluids.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that cause putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	¶ On the Incision for the Disease Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter XC.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This disease is called Nakir in our land: it is a pain that occurs in certain limbs and then shifts from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I have indeed seen it myself, as I am narrating to you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in some fields.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she showed me her arm, and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the brachium.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I remained there for one hour, I saw a swelling move with rapidity, as a worm moves, ascending to her shoulder faster than can be seen: it is like live silver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore, the pain receded from that place and fixed itself in her shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for one hour, and it ran through the rest of her body until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that it was moving throughout her entire body, as I had seen.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	Therefore I have wondered about the speed of its permutation from member to member.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed before that, I had not seen this illness so strangely according to this manner.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	Indeed, I have seen many who find the pain permute from member to member: and I did not see it with my eyes as I saw it in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not consider it to be so, unless it is because the woman was among those who are from the dry-bodied group with veins detected in the fields: hence this airiness is perceived as permuted.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and whose bodies are moist, for the veins are hidden.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	Therefore, when you wish to cure it, and the patient feels that pain: then if it is visible to your eye, as we said, then bind above it and below it quickly. Dry above it until the constricted airiness exits, and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If, however, you do not see it with your eyes: then treat it with the expulsion of the body, and with what expels airiness, and plug them with foul pills, and pills of serpentarum, and similar substances.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	¶ On the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Head XCVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows vary according to their species and according to the places where they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	The diversity of them is this: for some have large and small points, and others are concave and deaf.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And from them are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And among them are those that have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And among them are those that have teeth.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those that are according to members in which they fall, is according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For the members are from the principal parts concave, such as the brain, and the heart, and the liver, and the lung, and the kidneys, and the intestines, and the bladder, and similar ones.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into any of these members, and you see the signs of death, which I narrate to you afterward, then it is necessary to perform a timely extraction from them, for death follows him in whom it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these evil signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the member, then extract it, and take care of the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when the arrow falls into the brain and penetrates the nose and emerges through the nasal aperture which is above the brain, it is: for from that place violent nausea, blindness, dizziness, redness in the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasms, confusion of thought, and vomiting of cholera occur.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood comes out from the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And the white moisture emerges from the place of the wound similar to pus.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it exits there similar to the moisture of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore you see these signs, then abstain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it does not emerge.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the arrow when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left breast, and one feels as if it is fixed in a hard substance with it, not in a void.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the movement of the arrow is similar to the pulse: and black blood flows from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And follows that coldness of the extremities, and cold sweat, and syncope.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Therefore, you should know that death descends without doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of the arrow when it wounds the lung is the emergence of foamy blood from the wound: and the vessels which follow the neck become inflamed, and the color of the patient changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he exhales a great, deep breath: and seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	And if the arrow falls into the velayment, which is in the chest: then it is near the small ribs: and a great panting occurs with a severe pain, with a sigh: and all the arm muscles move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested from food emerges from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the abdomen and is fixed there: something of feces emerges from the wound, or that which is intestinal and already ruptured.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore, there is no hope in curing him, nor in extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow falls into the Bladder and exits through urine, and something proceeds from it to the exterior, causing greater pain to the patient: then know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The other limbs, such as the face, neck, throat, palate, assistance muscles, spine, ribs, thigh, leg, and similar parts, are treated according to various methods when the arrow does not hit an artery or nerve, and the arrow is not poisonous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I inform you of what I have seen about these arrows, so that you may understand this for your own treatment.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	Because an arrow fell into the lacrimal apparatus of one man and into the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore, I extracted it from him, on the opposite side, beneath the fat behind his ear: and he was cured, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which fell into the fat behind his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I could only grasp its small extremity, with which it adhered to its wooden part: and the arrow was large among the arrows of the Turkish bows, with soft iron, in which there are no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	Therefore, the Jew was cured, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted an arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was the Arabic arrow, and it is of those that have wings.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	Therefore I followed the arrow between the two guidegines, and it was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I extracted it carefully, until I removed it: and the Christian was cured.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from the man which had fallen into his belly: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed from him, and nothing had changed in his condition, I followed the arrow: and I carefully extracted it, and he was cured, and no ill happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man from whom an arrow had fallen on his back, and the wound had healed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After seven years had passed, an arrow emerged at the root of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman from whom an arrow had fallen into her belly, and the wound had healed over it, and the arrow remained within: and nothing had changed in her condition, and the woman found no harm in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man, from whom an arrow had fallen on his face: and the wound had healed, and it remained, not causing him much pain: and similar cases to these many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from one of the king's men, which had fallen into his nose, and was now slightly tilting towards the right side: and the entire arrow was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was therefore called upon to treat him after the arrow incident until three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found therefore the wound of the arrow to be very deep.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I therefore examined it with a fine probe, and did not sense it: and indeed he found a puncture and pain on the right side of his ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that it was that puncture from the tip of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I applied a plaster to the area with a plaster that had the properties of attracting and dissolving, and I trusted that the place would suppure and show me a sign of the arrow, so that I could cut above it: and no accident occurred in the place that would indicate that the arrow had reached the location.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I applied plaster to him frequently over many days: and no accident occurred, and the wound healed in the meantime: and he remained ill for a space of days after its removal until he felt the arrow within his nose on a certain day.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I therefore applied a sharp and corrosive medicine to the wound for many days until it opened up: and when I probed it, I felt the fine tip of the arrow adhering to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	I then added the sharp medicine to the open wound until we could clearly see the tip of the arrow: and it took me that time about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	I then, after the wound had enlarged and it became possible for me to introduce forceps into it and move them, and they did not obey my effort: then I continued to probe and devise methods for it until one day with well-made forceps, as the form of those will be described at the end of this chapter, I was able to extract it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the physicians indeed judge that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Therefore I restored it, and the wound was consolidated, and the patient was restored to complete health: nor did anything at all harm him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of the extraction of certain arrows: so that you may place that rule and meaning above what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not included in the narration: nor does the book encompass it, and a skilled craftsman compares it with a little more and a little less: and with that which is present, he compares it with what is absent: and he finds a new operation, and a new instrument at the descent of matters foreign to this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say that arrows do not exit from the limbs on which they are fixed, except according to two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or through attraction from the place whence it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or through the opposite part of the other.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which exits from where it entered, or is an arrow proceeding into a fleshy place and is attracted and exits.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	And if it does not conform to exiting at the time it falls, then it is necessary to let it go for a few days until the flesh around it putrifies. The attraction of it should be alleviated, and its exit facilitated.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly, if it is embedded in bone and does not conform to your desire for its exit, then let it go for a few days. Repeat the process with attraction and motion every day until it exits.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not yield to you for the outcome after days, then you must perforate through the groove of the arrow at the bone from every part with a sharp drill until the arrows enlarge.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out, and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If the arrow is fixed in the skull bone, and has already penetrated into one ventricle of the brain, and certain of the symptoms I said appear: then refrain from drawing out the arrow, and leave it until it comes to an equal state after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the brain, then death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, unless only in the bone of the body and does not penetrate all the way to the brain: and the patient remains ill for a few days, and nothing of those symptoms occurs to him: then proceed with drawing out the arrow and its extraction.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If it is fixed deeply, and does not yield to you for drawing out: then apply drills around the arrow, as I have described: then care for the wound until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If the arrow has already been hidden in the body and is concealed from sense: then seek it out by probing.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it out with instruments that are suitable for its extraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot draw it out due to the constriction of the wound and the length of the arrow deep within: and there is neither bone nor nerve nor vein there: then incise over it until the wound enlarges, making it possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If he has ears that can be held, then free the fixed flesh around them from every part, by all means thou canst, and means, if it cannot escape through the flesh by breaking of the ears or twisting them until it escapes.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when thou administerest the extraction of the Arrow, in whatever place it is, then use the twisting of thy hand, with forceps to all parts, until thou makest it escape: and with extreme subtlety, that the Arrow be not broken, and may become difficult for thee to draw it and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If thou canst not do it in one hour, then let it alone for a few days until what is about it putrefies.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: for it will be relieved by the operation. But if it resists thee with a counteraction of the flow of blood, then administer as we said in the chapter on cure and guard thy strength from incising the vein, or nerve, or chord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer the operation by every means thou canst for the escape of the Arrow: and let it be with facility, and tranquility, or tardiness, and firmness, as I have told thee.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And thou must do it when thou drawest the Arrow so that the patient is in the same condition as he was at the time of the Arrow's penetration.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If it is not possible for thee to do that, then administer what is possible for thee from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	For the Arrow which issues from the opposite side or is proceeding to the exterior: or causes a hump at the end of the Arrow through a sensation from the skin near the upper part, and thou seest it protruding: cut above it, and let the cut be according to the quantity that the forceps can grasp in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it: for itself it becomes easy to extract.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it is indeed retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness until the arrow presses into the bone and penetrates itself further: then draw it.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: let it alone for a few days, then repeat the procedure until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the arrow's shaft is in it, then push it along with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If the shaft has fallen off, and you need to apply a push: then insert a concave instrument into it, so that its concavity enters the arrowhead: then push it along with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then push it with an instrument entering into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow is propelled by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to incise all the flesh in which the poison is: if that is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then treat it according to what is suitable for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow is embedded in the chest, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or in the side: and it is close enough for you to feel it upon probing and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut it out, and be careful not to incise a vein or nerve, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then dress the wound if you see it, and treat it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of Forceps, with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let the ends be similar to the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp over the arrow, they do not let go of it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And many kinds, both large and small, are made from them, according to the size of the arrow, its thickness, and the width and contraction of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of the Impeller concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the Impeller blunt.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the blunt end like a radius, so that its entry into the concave arrow may be facilitated, and it may be pushed along with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The end of the impeller concave is concave like a bird's feather: so that the entry of the arrow into it may be facilitated and its impulse.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	¶ Concerning the Phlebotomy of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Head XCVII.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	Veins to be phlebotomized, for which the custom is commonly practiced, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of which sixteen are in the head: two pulsating veins, which are behind the ears and called the Two Herbs; and two arteries, which appear in the two temples; and two veins which are in the two lacrimal glands of the eyes, called the Aspicientes; and the Vena Praeparata in the middle of the forehead; and the vein which is at the tip of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two glands of Guidegy, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins which are phlebotomized in the arms are five veins in every arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is Cephalica, and it is from the side of the wild olive tree: and the common people name it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Median vein, and it is composed of the branch of Basilica and the branch of Cephalica: and the common people name it the body vein.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And Basilica, and it is placed on the domestic side: and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people name it the vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.
