And Funis brachii, and it is placed above the foelix: and it is that vein in which phlebotomy is performed, and it is that which appears above the thumb with a clear examination.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And Salvatoria: and it is the vein which is between the ring finger and the little finger: and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the thigh and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the curvature of the thumb from the side of sylvester.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is Saphena: and its place is at the heel from the side of domestic.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the first is Nesse: and its place is at the heel from the side of sylvester.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the thigh there are three veins similar to them.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	¶ Concerning the phlebotomy of two veins behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	Phlebotomy of the two veins which are behind the ears is beneficial for ancient catarrhs, hemigraine, sahafati, and old malignant ulcers of the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of phlebotomy for them is as I narrate.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is done by shaving the head of the sick person: and the back of his neck is rubbed at the place of the two veins with a rough cloth for good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the sick person should tie his neck with a bandage until the two veins become visible.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And the places of these veins are behind the ears in two depressed areas of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Seek out these veins with your finger, and where you feel the pulse of these veins under your finger, mark those places with cautery.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the phlebotomy knife, which is called Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein in the skin until the phlebotomy reaches the vein opening.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then raise your hand with the vein and skin to the upper part, and cut the vein with the skin by a cutting incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And the length of the incision shall be the width of two joined fingers, or about that: and let blood flow out as much as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then ligate it with sutures and remove it until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And the cutting and cauterization of them have already been treated at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	¶ Concerning phlebotomy of two arteries at the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Of the two arteries that are at the temples, phlebotomy is beneficial for ancient headache, malignant headache, and continuous eye disease: and for the course of excessive flowing sharp fluid to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of phlebotomy for these is as I am about to tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The sick person should tighten his neck much until two veins become clearly apparent to the touch, and their pulse should be demonstrated by your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then apply the cautery with hot oil.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then raise the skin above the vein to the upper part with your index finger, and insert the phlebotomy instrument entering from below, and raise the vein to the upper part.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it, as you did with the other two veins: and let blood flow out in the amount necessary to you.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then release the compression on the sick person, and place your finger on the vein for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	After place over the abscess and poultices, and bind it tightly from above with constriction: and release it until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now the recall of those has come, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	¶ Concerning the phlebotomy of the frontal vein after cephalic phlebotomy.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The ligature of the phlebotomy of the frontal vein is to be performed after cephalic phlebotomy for ancient diseases of the face: and for hemigraine, and for liver spots: and for foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is as I shall tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The sick person should draw his neck with the fingers, until the vein becomes apparent.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument called Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Of which this is the form.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place a prominent point at the head of the Fossorium over the vein, and strike above it with a plectrum or some other object in the same manner, and release the blood to flow according to the quantity you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then release the puncture and bind it tightly until it is healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes it is opened with a broad phlebotomy.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	Indeed, it should not be a sharp-extremity phlebotomy, as are the other phlebotomies, but rather a broad-extremity one.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And perform phlebotomy on it according to inclination, for the vein is nearby: and perhaps the phlebotomus will break when it is thin.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of Phlebotomy of the Veins in the Two Lacrimal Glands.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The ligament of the two veins that are in the two lacrimal glands is for the eye from scabies and rubescence: and it swells in the eye, and facial ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of phlebotomy for this is that the sick person tightens his neck with a woody rod.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then perform phlebotomy on them: and you stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And perform the phlebotomy according to inclination at a slight length, using a small, slightly broad phlebotomus, for there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	For if the phlebotomus is thin at the tip, it may break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let there be flowed out as much blood as is necessary to you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place warm compresses over them, and tighten them with one night's bandage, then release them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of Phlebotomy of the Veins of the Nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The phlebotomy of the veins of the nose is applied to acute fever, sore throat with intense pain, and facial ailments such as hemigraine and rubescence that occur on the face, particularly when they are chronic.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is that the sick man will stretch his neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold his nose with your left hand, and take a fine, long lancet: and fix it in the middle of its muzzle, between that which distinguishes the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the veins do not appear to the touch there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And you should move your hand with the lancet slightly: and let the blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then ligate it on the same night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it restores itself quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	¶ Of Phlebotomy of Veins, by Guidehi.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	Of Guidehi's phlebotomy, the benefit is for the constriction of dyspnea, the onset of leprosy, melancholic illnesses, impetigo, and malignant sores, as well as for corrodents, that is, erythematous lesions.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of these phlebotomies is that the sick man will be ligated under both sides of his neck: and the artisan shall stand over the sick man's head, and the sick man shall sit on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then make the phlebotomy along the vein somewhat wide in length.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw a适量的血量，或根据你所见的情况按需要抽取。
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	After this, cut the ligament, and tie the two veins with a tight thread: so that the sick person is not overheat.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let her remain thus until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The wound is healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	§ On Phlebotomy of the Veins in Albucasis.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	Veins in Albucasis are used for phlebotomy because they promote alkolism in the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and bad ulcers, and cracks in the lips, and bad ulcers, even those found in the nose and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of these veins for phlebotomy is that you make the sick person sit before you, and tie his neck with a band.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then roll back the lip and look for two veins: of which one is on the right side of the lip, and the second on the left side of him: and the demonstration of both is through the blackness of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that is true: because around them are small black veins.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore cut both with an incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If there is any doubt for you, and you do not know which one it is: then direct your attention to the larger incision, and make that more apparent.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly do for the two veins in the upper lip: and indeed, custom directs much with this. And cut the two veins which are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	§ On Phlebotomy of the Vein under the Tongue after Cephalic Phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	Of the two Veins which are beneath the tongue for phlebotomy: it is that the Cephalic phlebotomy is for affections which are in the throat, and the illness of the uvula, and illnesses of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomy for these is that the sick person sit between your hands in the sun: and elevate his tongue, and look under his tongue on one side one vein, and on the other side another vein: and the color of both declines to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Phlebotomize therefore both: and watch, that you do not place your hand too close in phlebotomy.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For beneath them are arteries, and perhaps there may be a flow of blood from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three Veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three Veins which are phlebotomized in the elbow are in which phlebotomy custom has run throughout all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And phlebotomy of them is done according to two modes.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by puncturing with a wide phlebotomy lancet of myrtle: or by cutting very finely: or by cutting with a surgical knife, and this is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is, which agrees with cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these there are broad and fine species according to the width of the veins and their strictures. The form of the myrtle phlebotomy should be broad, as you can see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening concave, full, outgoing, visible, thick veins, and those that contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomy is of lesser width and finer at the ends.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for phlebotomy of fine veins, which contain thin yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	¶ Of the Phlebotomy of Basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	Basilica, however, which is one of these three veins, is beneficial for phlebotomy.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from illnesses that are below the throat and neck, as it follows the chest and abdomen. And it is suitable for the phlebotomist to use this vein, but he should be careful, for there is an artery beneath it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he errs and adds to the point of phlebotomy, he will hit that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore, it is necessary to use this vein with the non-puncturing phlebotomus, not with the puncturing one.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If Basilica does not appear with a clear manifestation, then it is necessary to locate it and exchange for another vein, or you may seek one of its branches: or use the location of this vein for the phlebotomy of the arm.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	It is clear and should be used with the non-puncturing phlebotomus Anesil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to perform phlebotomy at this location, then it is necessary to tie the arm first, so that you may touch the place until you recognize the pulse location.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the place with cauterization, afterwards the arm, and cut the vein with a concave incision using the phlebotome Alnesil, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And beware that the blow does not fall through the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, when you tighten the ligature, inflation at the place you marked with cauterization, then that inflation is from the artery: avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	And if you see blood spurt at the phlebotome as urine from a boy, and it is thin, red blood: then know that it is from the blood of the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Therefore hurry, and place your finger over the space longwise, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore blood is cut (for it is cut many times), then tie the arm, and release it: and let the patient beware of its motion: and let him be afraid of it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And let it not move for several days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If, however, blood is not cut and it overcomes you, and you have no medicine present at the moment, then cut the artery if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities are drawn together, and blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a strip of elm bark, and cut it. Take half of it, and tie it over the place of vein compression with a ligature and pledgets until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then take care of it with him from whom the mention preceded concerning the place where the flow of blood is stopped by dust: and the cutting off of the blood of this is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the location of the small wound, and the possibility of ligature from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	¶ Of Phlebotomy of the Blue Vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	But the Blue Vein is useful for phlebotomy, which draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: therefore, because it is composed of a branch of the Basilic vein and a branch of the Cephalic vein, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is suitable for the phlebotomist that she/he be above the fear of phlebotomy, for beneath her/him is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore she/he adds a puncture in the phlebotomy and finds a nerve, a stupor occurs in it, and the healing of her/him becomes difficult, and perhaps she/he is not cured at all.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If however it is hidden in some people and is fine and not shown, then you must place your phlebotomy where you draw blood from it, following the Alnési method, and avoiding the nerve with your skill.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein is between two nerves, then cut the vein lengthwise.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	¶ Of the Cephalic Vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	Phlebotomy of cephalic veins is beneficial for bloodletting, because it draws blood from the head, and contributes to ailments of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is proper in this vein, if you wish, to perform phlebotomy by puncturing it with a lancet of olive wood or with a myrtle branch, for it is safer among all veins, for it is neither an artery nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	Nevertheless, it is advisable for you during phlebotomy to use only the head of the lancet and seek a milder spot: and it does not harm if it is not found on the first strike, so that the lancet may be applied to it several times with phlebotomy.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Nevertheless, perhaps an aposteme [suppurated abscess] develops in some people when not phlebotomized on the first strike, but it does not harm them if such an aposteme appears elsewhere.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the Utility of Phlebotomy and Cautions to Be Observed Therein.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy, and its accidents arising from it, which you should consider in its correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First, you should know what it is about, that phlebotomy is not performed except for the preservation of health, and its continuance, and caution against the approach of illness.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And for phlebotomy to be performed in one of the three veins located in the elbow, namely, the cephalic, the basilic, and the femoral.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And for phlebotomy to be performed at the beginning of Spring on an empty stomach, in spring and summer: in autumn and winter after a meal, when signs of excess are evident.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And let the bloodletting be on the first day, or the third day, after three hours have passed from the day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomia, which is administered in illnesses, does not have a fixed hour: but when provoked by convenience and necessity for that, it can be done at night, or during the day, and at every hour, and at every time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not proper to bleed children until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor shall a pregnant woman be bloodlet except from the fourth month until the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor shall old men be bloodlet who have already passed sixty years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When therefore someone wishes to be bloodlet for any reason at all: it is necessary that he purify his bowels before bloodletting with a gentle enema, if there is much feces retained in them: so as not to draw from the veins at bloodletting noxious foul excretions from the intestines into the body's principal parts.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor shall a patient who has colic, that is, severe nausea, be bloodlet; nor one who is intoxicated, nor one who has just recovered from intoxication, until that is removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor shall a patient with dropsy be bloodlet.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And bloodletting should be avoided again after colic, vomiting, flux of the bowels, increase in sexual activity, labor, exercise, watchfulness, fasting, and all that dissolves virtue from the bodily or animal substance.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider in subtlety of humors before that, if blood is thick with foods and drinks and medicines: if it is possible for him that.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then enter the bath if nothing prevents it; or exercise with some exercise to thin the blood.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And let him undergo phlebotomy on the third day, as we said, and try that his chest be evacuated on that day from all animal evils: such as distress, anger, and fear: and from all bodily evils, such as labor, pain, excess of urine, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let there be present at his seat things of whose use custom among men has arisen from the aroma, fragrance, and pleasure, and similar things according to the quantity possible.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the phlebotomist sit on a higher bench than the phlebotomy couch: afterwards extend his arm and let the phlebotomist rub it twice or three times with his hand.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tie the ligament with pincers and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the tie be适度的，因为当捆扎不均匀，或是因过度紧绷时，都会阻碍血液流动；同样，在放松时也会阻碍血液流动。
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the tie, let the patient rub his arms reciprocally until the veins become distended and are apparent to the touch.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then let the phlebotomist cleanse the patient with a little old oil.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he shall place his left hand's index finger upon the vein at the spot where he wishes to perform phlebotomy, gently: so that the vein does not flee, and percussion may be administered.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Since you find the vein as one fleeing like a string at phlebotomy: and from there is that which is full of wind: and when you place the lancet upon it, it contracts beneath the lancet, deceiving the person holding the lancet, and the lancet does not open the vein: and if it does open it, it is narrowed. Therefore, for this reason, it is necessary to strengthen the lancet and be vigilant in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he shall lay down the lancet.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore the vein opens from one prick, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then prick again at another place nearby, or above that place with haste: so that the spot does not become inflamed.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If, however, the spot becomes inflamed or the patient grows worse, then let him rest for a day, or two days: and do not bind with a bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	For it might draw a hot inflammation.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Neither shall he enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then he may repeat the phlebotomy if he wishes.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small, or the blood flows slowly: and be careful that a quantity different from what you wish does not emerge from the blood: then prick again at the same hole according to its exact position, and add a little during the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do that with urgency before the place suppurates, for the suppuration of the place occurs in many people during the operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you therefore see it already suppurating, then you will not operate on it at all, for nothing excuses you in this regard.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place something from the oil ointment over it: for it will facilitate the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than oil itself, and than other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the oil ointment in all bloodletting where you let blood from veins during the prohibition of blood flow: and they do this with Tyriac, Alfarac, and Sagzenea, when placed over the area.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood is thinned and resolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	And if suppuration occurs in the area of bloodletting, a large abscess often happens, especially to those who are bled only at that time, or there is a small opening in the vein. Then act quickly and place a sponge soaked in water and salt on the area, slightly heated: and hold it for a moment; for it will resolve.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And you should do that after the blood has exited the vein itself, either with its complement or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	And if something remains in the area after a few days, such as blackness or greenishness, this is not harmful: and if you wish, place something from aloe or myrrh on it that will resolve it, or some juice from mint, i.e., calamus or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And indeed, boils and swellings often occur after phlebotomy at the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore place your hand upon it, then if you find it soft upon compressing it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, be careful to place something upon it from what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood from an artery is flowing from it.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make him a poultice with it containing styptic material, so that the area may be hardened.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then attend to it with the rest of the treatment until it is cured.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to draw from every person all the blood in proportion to the strength of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what is apparent from the color prevailing over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is dark, then let it be allowed to exude until it becomes red: and similarly, if you see it thick, then let it be allowed to exude until it becomes finer: and similarly, if it is sharp, then let its sharpness be removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for one who is full, strong, and needs a bloodletting with only one incision, that the phlebotomy of the vein be enlarged, and let the bloodletting be broad: and in one who is weak, the opposite should be done.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to draw it off alternately, and let the opening be narrow: and it is better in a phlebotomy of a vein that there be a transverse section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood, and from the cutting of a nerve: and it is more commendable, and safer than phlebotomy by breadth and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And for those to whom it is accustomed to come upon during phlebotomy by syncopis, it ought that food be given before phlebotomy a small amount of bread infused in pomegranate water: or secana bin, if it is heated: and let him draw from the blood in three courses, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if it is of a cold temperament, then let him take before phlebotomy bread infused in myrtle syrup, or in aromatic honey syrup, or in fragrant syrup aromatized with spices.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	And if syncopal attack occurs during phlebotomy, and the cause of its death is the escape of much blood, then it ought that he take for drink water of meat and fragrant subtle syrup: and use aromatic with algalia, and liniment his breast with it: and use the rest which we said in the division in the chapter on syncopal attack from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	And whoever wishes to treat his arm and relieve his blood secondarily: it ought that for him, whose phlebotomy is for the purpose of strong evacuation, and his strength is weak, he relieve his blood gradually according to the quantity of his strength over continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	And whoever wishes to treat his arm and relieve his blood secondarily, and his body is strong: then let him do this seven or nine hours after his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	And whoever wishes to draw blood from his body to the opposite part of the one toward which it declines: it ought to be treated on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body there is much blood already heated and sharpened, and causes fever: it is necessary that the blood go out of him through one vein, and a large quantity be drawn from him: and the opening should be enlarged until syncope occurs: after which you must preserve all conditions of phlebotomy: and you shall place your hand upon his pulse at the course of the blood, that death not occur in place of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For it often happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant and falls into negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not necessary when you wish to let the arm sweat and release the blood a second time, if the opening of the vein is already closed and the exit of the blood becomes difficult, so that it must be pressed upon with frenzy and the wound extended quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is very evil; indeed, leave it until the phlebotomy is performed a second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove it with the sharpness of the phlebotomy that which has coagulated from blood in the opening of the vein, and place something of dissolved salt on top.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place something on top of it from tyriaca, alfarroba, or sagzenea, and apply it with gentle compression until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If the vein is indeed an apostema, then leave it alone and do not treat it until the apostema subsides.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If necessity prompts you to let the blood a second time, and there is no excuse, then either perform phlebotomy above that place, or on another arm at another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But the vein of the arm for phlebotomy is marked by Fuscae and Basilicae; and when they are not found, and are hidden, because it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of its phlebotomy is that the sick person should introduce his hand into warm water until it becomes red, and the veins will appear manifestly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it is tied above it with a ligature with only moderate constriction in the middle.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then perform the phlebotomy obliquely, not laterally nor along its length: and let the incision be wide, and your phlebotomy be such that you make it obliquely above the joint of the hand slightly.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the outflow of blood is prevented, then immerse your hand in warm water again, and allow the blood to flow in the water until you achieve what you need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If you are in the days of summer, then you may avoid immersing your hand in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And the flow of blood in warm water is greatest during the winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this vein is safer than all others, because there is no pulse-bearing vein or nerve beneath it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The phlebotomy of the Saluatella of the right hand is conducive to diseases of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of its phlebotomy is that you tie the mahason of the hand with a ligature or your hand, after you introduce it into warm water, until the vein becomes evident and is strongly perceptible to the touch.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then incise it transversely for phlebotomy.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you incise it completely, it will not harm him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And conserve, lest you withdraw your hand with the phlebotome.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For beneath it are the nerves of the fingers stripped of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then pass your hand to the hot water, and let the blood run in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not pass it in hot water, the blood will coagulate at the opening of the vein and be prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	For when you have drawn from the blood the quantity necessary, then place oil and salt over the vein: so that it does not constrict quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly, you should do this with every tightly drawn vein.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The ligature for the phlebotomy on the left hand is: because it is conducive to spleenic diseases. And similarly, do this for the other phlebotomy, as you did for the second one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The ligature for the saphenous phlebotomy is for diseases of the lower part of the body, such as uterine disorders, retention of menstruation, kidney ailments, and old sores of the thighs and legs, and similar diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that the patient should insert his foot into hot water and apply friction until the veins become prominent: then ligate above the ankle joint with a ligature.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And there is a vein indeed in the region of the heel, visible opposite the thumb: and from it branch out many branches on the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, let phlebotomy be performed on it in a larger branch thereof, or in the region of the heel at its confluence: for this is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If you perform phlebotomy on it on the face of the foot, then be careful of the nerves that are beneath it on the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And make your phlebotomy through it, as if you wish to incise it, and call the phlebotomy Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If, however, the outlet of the blood is forbidden, then bathe his foot in warm water: and let the blood flow into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the vein for phlebotomy is in the first branch, then repeat with phlebotomy to the upper parts slightly, for the place is safe, and you should not fear any harm from it, provided you are careful of the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the Saphena vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the Sciatic veins, as we have said, is in the heel from the side of the wild beast.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the remedy for phlebotomy of it is for pain in the hip when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is that the sick person should go into the bath and hurry. Bind his leg from the side of the hip up to above the heel with four fingers using a thin long bandage: for it does not appear otherwise.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When therefore it appears, then let the phlebotomy be made according to whatever skill is possible to you, or by turning: and it is better, or that you cut it by incision, or divide it by section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	The place thereof is safer, and it is hidden in many men greatly.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and it does not appear at all to the sense: then let the phlebotomy be made of some branch thereof, and that is the one which appears on the back of the foot and towards the ear: and beware of the nerves, and cause a quantity of blood to flow as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then release the tension, and place skin over the site of phlebotomy, and tighten the area.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For it is quickly cured.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	¶ On Ventosation and the quality of its use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter CVIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Ventoza are produced from horns, and from air, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And ventosation is made according to two methods.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	When with scarification and bloodletting: and the other is ventosation without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this ventosation which is without scarification is according to two methods.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventosations administered with scarification and bloodletting are fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	One is Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is after the head: and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck: and ventosae Alhagdim, and they are two laminae of the neck from both parts together: and ventosae menti, and it is under the mandible in the lower lip: and ventosae duarum spatularum: and ventosae Alachosos above the end of the tail: and ventosae duorum focilium, and they are in the middle of the two arms: and ventosae duorum crurium: and ventosae duarum cauillarum.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And ventosatio indeed does not draw blood from you from small veins scattered in the flesh, and for this reason, its virtue does not fail as it does with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor should ventosatio be administered with or without fire for any illness that occurs from congestion until the entire body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity provokes ventosatio from illness or for the sake of custom, we administer it at any hour at the beginning of the month, at the end of the month, and in the middle of the month, and at whatever time it is needed.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	This is because some people find that when blood multiplies in their body until it needs to be extracted through ventosatio, they experience heaviness and soreness in their head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And among them are those who find congestion and redness on their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And among them are those who find itching on their face, forehead, and darkness and dullness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And there is one who slits the place for his ventilation.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And there is one whose laughter is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And there is one who finds the taste of blood in his mouth: or his tongue swells, and he spits out blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And there is one whose sleep is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And there is one who sees in his sleep blood and rust, and slain persons, and wounds, and things similar to these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	Therefore, when we see anything from these symptoms, and properly if it is in the middle of the third week: then we order ventilation to be performed after two or three hours have passed from the day.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The collaret of the ventilation for the neck is: because it contributes to heaviness in the head, and what is poured down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it should be done after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this ventilation is equivalent to cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not advisable for those with a cold complexion or where there is a catarrh to use this.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it causes great harm to them.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And for that reason, it is not advisable for old people or those with cold ailments in their head to use this.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever becomes an assiduous user of this will experience a loss of memory.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for this reason, you should command the Ventosator to withdraw his hand with the ventosa momentarily toward the inferiors, fearing the generation of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosatio or Alkehel is in the place of phlebotomiae Fuscae and phlebotomiae Basilicae, and for this reason contributes to asmati, and constriction of breathing, and fissures of the instrument causing breathing difficulties, and coughing, and filling up.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it should be pressed slightly with the ventosa Alkehel, for if placed downward, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosatio alhagdahim, contributes to headaches, and ophthalmia, and hemigraine, and perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is in the place of phlebotomiae Basilicae.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And you should command the Ventosator not to press his hand with the scarification: lest he hit an artery and cause a blood flow.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Ventosatio under the chin, contributes to halitosis in the mouth, and gingival decay, and similar conditions from diseases of the mouth: and it is in the place of another phlebotomy, which is located in the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Ventosatio with the spatula, contributes to alchafacham, which results from folding and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	Ventosatio of the internal parts of two focilium, contributes aid to phlebotomy of veins of three kinds: Basilicae, Fuscae, and Cephalicae: for it draws blood from all those small veins in the flesh. And those small veins draw from other larger veins until the drawing reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And you must instruct the Wind Doctor that he should not proceed too much in scarification: for the place is stripped of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	Ventosa applied over the alchausos confers hemorrhoids and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And you must instruct the Wind Doctor that the ventosa should be large, and made of air: for the place requires a strong suction, and perhaps the fine wind cups break: and scarification should be done with a large incision.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	However, wind cups reduce the swelling of the legs by a clear diminution: for they draw blood from the entire body, and cause old pains in the kidneys, uterus, and bladder: they provoke menstruation, and bothor and ademenul: and stand in place of phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they greatly weaken the body and cause syncope to occur in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the effect of wind cups on alhorcobeni is similar to the effect of wind cups on both crurium.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of wind cups is that you should place the wind cup first in a vacuum and draw a tempered suction: and do not prolong the position of the wind cups, but place them quickly and remove them quickly, so that the fluids come to the place of their arrival equally: and do not cease to repeat this continuously until you see the place already turning red and swelling, and the redness of the blood appears: then scarify, and iterate the suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For one who is of tender flesh and has rare pores, it should be incised once, not more: lest the place ulcerate.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And command the Suctioner to enlarge the incision and penetrate only slightly: and regulate the suction with regard to ease, speed, and gentle movement.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is thickness in the blood, then it should be incised twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first incision, the way for the subtle removal of blood and its moisture is opened: and in the second, a thorough exploration for the extraction of thick blood is made.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is exceedingly foul, then make the incision a third time: so that the ultimate [treatment] may be achieved.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And for the ultimate purpose, when we wish to extract blood gradually or slightly, one incision is sufficient.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to extract much blood, we incise with multiple incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure and find that the blood is thick, then it should be incised with a deep incision. And the depth of the incision is the equal limit.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What should be administered from oils during the placement of suction, and what the suctioner should beware of.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	For those whose skin is thick, hard, and dark, and whose pores are narrow, the areas should be anointed with suction using open, soothing, and resolving oils: if it is in the summer season, such as almond oil, or jasmine oil, or oil of sweet almonds, or oil of cucumber.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the time of winter, then use narcissus oil, or lily oil, or chamomile oil, or spikenard: and similar substances.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If the excess is large and cold, then use bitter almond oil, or balsam oil, or white oil, or etherine oil: and similar substances.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If the windward humor is of large pores, tender flesh: then it must be prevented by oil, and they should wash the places of the windy humor after windation with rose water, or with cold water, or with solar water, or with cucumber water, or with purslane water: and similar substances.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He whose blood is of much humidity should wash windy places with vinegar, or with myrtle water, and sumac: and similar substances.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	He whose excesses are large should wash his windy places with old wine, or with samsuc water, or with aether infusion, or chamomile infusion: and similar substances.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it must be ensured that windation is performed in a bath, or on the site of the bath, or it must be administered for one hour, or two hours, after exiting the bath.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not advisable for anyone to sleep after windation.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What must be done to regulate the windward humor or phlebotomy before windation.
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after this, you should consider first: then if the winded or phlebotomized person is choleric, and the acidity and inflammation overcome the blood: then he should take cooling substances, such as pomegranate juice. And also endive with vinegar and lettuce, and safflower, and juleb: and similar substances.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And place his food in small portions, and meats of quail provoke fever, and seasoned foods with herbs: and to them similar.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And of whose constitution is cold, it ought to take for drink syrup of honey, or of almond, or else asclepiad of seeds made: and let him take medium fragrant wine, which is between old and new: and let it be prescribed that he use scarcity of food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And place his food in small portions, and canebir: and passeres, that is, small birds: and pullos columborum issuadet.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it ought to be that the drink on days of ventilation and phlebotomy be more than food: and in some people it should be given as a drink at times tyriaca alfaroch, or medicine of musk, that is, mace, or alesselithe before ventilation: and before phlebotomy, or after: so that the principal members may be strengthened, and the blood refined.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it ought not to be taken in heated drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	¶ Of Ventilation Without Scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	Ventosae however, which are without scarification, are those ventilations placed over the liver, spleen, and podagram, and over the abdomen, umbilicus, and regions of the kidneys and spine: for these members do not bear scarification upon them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And it is not sought through them, except by contact from the blood member to another member: as we place ventilation over the breasts in the illness of nasal bleeding.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we make use of them, that we may relieve the cold and intermitting wind in the member: as when we place a ventosa (suction cup) on the belly, and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it rarifies the member, and heats it, and relieves the pain therefore, because it resolves that wind.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	And likewise placed upon the kidneys when there occurs ophilitation or stone therein.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	By the virtue of its attraction, it perhaps opens the ophilitation, or removes the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And similarly it is done when placed upon the ear and the spleen for the purpose of fomenting the wind in both.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these ventosas are administered with empty cups using only a cut.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are applied with heat.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are applied full of warm water in cases of pleurisy: and this is done that the ventosa be filled, and may be large, with warm water alone, or with water in which herbs that are suitable have been decocted.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	§ The form of the ventosa applied with heat.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	The size of its opening should be that of two open fingers, as we have formed it. Its depth should be the width of a palm's half. In the middle of its side, near its midpoint, there should be a small hole through which an awl can fit, according to its size. It should be made of copper or brass, thick-walled, thin-walled, equally thick, and polished, so as not to injure the member where it is placed upon it. Through its middle, a rod made of wood or iron should be placed where the candle with fire is applied.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And now this suction is made great, greater than that which we have narrated, and not much less than that, according to the ailments and his age who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For the suction instruments for children and slender bodies are different from those for adults and robust bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of placing this suction instrument with fire on the limb is to light a wick with a small lamp made of rush or a small candle of tallow and place it over the middle of the crossbar which is in the center of the suction device: so that the flame is near the lower part of the suction device, so that the body of the sick person is not burned.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then it is placed on the limb: and the finger is placed over the hole which I said, until when we hold the suction device: as needed, we remove the finger, and the vapor will exit through that hole, and the suction device will immediately release.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then light the wick with the fire according to its measure, and repeat it if you need to do so.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	In the suction device used in the condition of pleurisy with water, there is no crossbar or hole: and it is not applied unless it is filled with water and placed only on the limb.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this suction device is better the more it is large, so that it can hold much water.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	¶ Concerning the Suspension of Sanguisugae.
Caput XCIX.	Chapter XCIX.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Sanguisugae are not applied in many cases, except where the application of suction devices on the limbs is not possible due to their thinness, such as the lip, gums, and similar areas.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or on a member stripped of flesh, as with a finger, and nose, and similar parts.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of using them is: as from the wounds of bloodsucking creatures which are in sweet waters, clean from putrefaction.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they are washed day and night in sweet water until they become flabby, and nothing remains in their intestines.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body should be evacuated first with phlebotomy, and with purges.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then cleanse the affected member until it becomes reddened.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Then place them over it.
