Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When they are full and fall off, and suction can be applied with a sponge, then this is more effective in healing. And if not, then wash the area with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then wash it with much water, rub it, and squeeze it.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the course of the blood is prolonged after the removal of the bloodsucking creature and it continues to exude fluid, then soak a linen cloth in cold water and place it over the area until the exuding stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the blood increases, then dust powdered tragacanth or gamboge, and similar substances from styptics, over it until the bleeding stops.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or place halves of depilated faba beans over the area and wash them until the beans adhere to the area, for the blood will stop.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And it is necessary to change the bloodsucking creatures if their repetition is needed and it is possible.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	If however sucking worms are prohibited from being applied due to suspension, then the place should be cleansed with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Pierce with a needle in the place until something comes out of the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then they are placed, for when they feel something from the blood, they adhere immediately.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When therefore you wish for them to fall off, sprinkle something powdered from bitter almond, or salt, or ashes over them, and they will fall off immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	§ End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	§ Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part III.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	§ General Discussion on Restoration, Dislocation, and Cure of Torsions and Similar Conditions.
Caput I.	§ Head I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This Chapter is also frequently necessary in the art of Medicine, and it deals with the restoration of fractures and dislocations in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	You know, my Sons, that fools and the common people boast about this Chapter, and they are those who have never examined an ancient book nor read a single letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And for this reason, this method is lacking in our land due to scientific knowledge.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I have never found anything entirely good in it, and I have not acquired that which I have acquired except due to the length of reading the ancient books, and the study beyond mere understanding of them, until I extracted that knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then by experience and study of the length of my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have described to you from that in this Chapter all that contains my science: and regarding what has exceeded the limits of my experience, after abbreviating it for you and freeing it from the occupation of elongation, and abbreviating it at the end of abbreviation, and showing it at the end of declination: and I formed in it many forms from the forms of instruments which are administered in it, since it is by the addition of declination, as I did in the two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	Summary and collections are necessary for the fracture of bones, from those of which a preliminary discussion is required before we begin the recollection of fractured and various members.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	We must, as we said in the prologue of this Chapter, provide summaries of the discourse and heads of topics, for which understanding the craftsman is first required to be stationed above their truth: namely, that you, and those who are willing, may know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say that when a fracture, or dislocation, or twisting, or fall occurs to someone, then it is necessary first to hasten to bleed him and to release him, either by one method or both simultaneously: if nothing prevents this, such as a weakening of strength: or the person who has been affected is a child or an old decrepit man: or it is a time of intense heat or intense cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then he should be content with his food of cold vegetables and bird meats and haws: and prohibit wine, and fatty meats, and be filled from foods and all food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	When you are secure from the hot abscess, and fear no outflow of matter into the limb, then the sick person may return to his former regimen with which custom usually proceeded.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When therefore the broken bone begins to heal, then it must be that the sick person is fed on nourishing foods with much, large, heavy nutrition in which there is fleshiness: such as food made from boiled wheat with water, rice, heads, feet, and bellies of cattle, eggs, and fresh fish: and thick wine, and similar substances.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	With this regimen, the coagulation of the fracture is made to occur more quickly and more effectively.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And know that broken bones, when they are in men who are in the first stage of old age and decrepit, cannot always be maintained and strengthened according to their natural state because of the drying out of their limbs: and those that are consolidated and continuous are like those of young children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	However, nature attaches something resembling glue from every side of the broken bone, which has thickness and adheres and tightens it until it is glued together and bound together until it reaches the end of strength and firmness as it was at first, so long as nothing prevents its actions. For this reason, it is necessary to provide the sick person with food that has heaviness, fleshiness, and thickness, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And know that the species of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of the limbs: for a fracture of the thigh is different from a fracture of the skull bone; and a fracture of the rib bone is different from a fracture of the spinal bone; and similarly all other limbs are diverse among themselves: and I have come with the remembrance of every species of fracture exposed in my chapter, distinguished from one another.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And varieties of bone fracture are diversified even within itself.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	Since it may occur that a curved fracture happens, besides which there may be splinters.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And sometimes a fracture occurs along the length of the bone: and there are fractures that are satagiae, that is, splinters, and additions proceeding, as in a reed when it is fitted with a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And not proceeding: and it is a fracture with a wound and disruption at the head: and it is a fracture with a small crack.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And there is an appropriate art or instrument for the restoration of each kind, as will be remembered in its own place.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from the way a bone fracture is recognized, there is its tortuosity and prominence: and its appearance to the senses, and the sound it makes when you compress it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	Therefore, when tortuosity is not apparent in place, nor sound upon touch when you compress the bone with your hand, and the patient does not find great pain: then there is no fracture there. Rather, it is possible that there is tortuosity or a small crack. Therefore, it is not necessary to move it with your hand and apply complete compression; rather, place it on top of what comes from medicines, as will be remembered after the appropriate moment for that place. Then, tighten the constriction gently.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And know that when the place is curved and split into two parts, besides which there may be splinters, yet every part is removed from its proper position: then you must begin at your appointed hour for correcting it, equalizing it before any hot abscess occurs.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	If however it happens that he has hot abscess, then let him be given for some days until the abscess subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then let him be given water in whatever manner is gentle and skillful.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And know that the restoration and adjustment of it is easier than bones where satagiae occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then bind it, according to whatever recall of it comes to you.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	If however there are satagiae in the bone, then extension of this fractured member from two parts is necessary, if it be a hand or foot: or with your hand, if it be a smaller limb: or with two threads, or with a thread and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And let your position be such that you place the limb on an equal spot according to its natural figure, until when the parts of the fractured member are extended; then try to restore all the additions with every skill and in any manner you can at their proper places. And beware according to your strength, lest through your operation pain happen to the weak part or injury occur: and try according to your strength to apply one of the two bones with its fellow bone according to better forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	And you must at that time try and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If therefore you see something different there, correct it and adjust it by the measure of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And beware of excessive extension and strong compression, as many careless people do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	For many times they cause hot abscess or contraction in the limb to occur through their operation, as we have already seen in their operations many times.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then annex after the equation, and the proper operation, and the stricture of that member, and rest, and tranquility: and bid the sick person upon it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And make him beware, lest he move it in the hour of his vigil, and during his sleep at the revolution of his body, and agitation, and during his defecation, and all his motions with his last strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And let him beware, lest the position of the member be such that it causes pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	Which is because when he feels pain or injury in the position of the member, then it is necessary to change it to another position where he does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And beware with him, that the position be equal and straight, so as not to cause any torsion in the member when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the stricture of the fractured member is as I narrate.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	Know that fractured members vary in their size and magnitude, and their form.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	Therefore, for those that are small, such as the arm, the finger, and the foot, and similar parts, then it is necessary that there be an wrapping of a soft, fine cloth.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	Those that are large, such as the thigh and the leg, should be wrapped with a broad, hard bandage.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	For a broad ligament connects the large member and tightens it from all sides with an equal stricture, so that it does not penetrate the member with any mark.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then begin after your evacuation from the equation by applying the ointment suitable for that over soft cloth upon the place of the fracture.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to wrap the ligament over the place of the fracture three times, or four, according as the limb merits: and draw your hand slightly with the ligament.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then go with it to the upper part from the place of the fracture, and draw less tightly than you drew the place of the fracture.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then extend yourself with the wrap from the place of the fracture slightly, and gradually soften the tension until you obtain a large amount from the healthy area.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another strip and wrap it again over the fractured area three times or four times.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Then go with the wrap to the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And let your operation be in the tension and softening of the wrap, as we said in the first upper wrap.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then place between the wraps a soft cloth or a piece of cloth that matches the curvature of the fracture, if there is any curvature: and if not, do not place anything there.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then wrap another strip over the first.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	Then apply heat to these wraps immediately, if there is no swelling and no warm abscess.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	If there is swelling or an abscess there, then place over it what suits that abscess, and remove the swelling: and let it remain for a few days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then stitch over the thenaeastellas.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And let the astellae be made from the midribs of wide, smoothed, and well-formed canes: or let them be made from wood used for making screens, which are made from pine or palm branches, or calingi: and let the width of all astellae be according to this form and this same figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	Yet the astella which is placed over the very wound should be somewhat thicker and wider: and the length of the astella should be according to the size and perfection of the member.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then stitch over the astellae with another thread according to the first incision.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then ligate from above with threads in the center, as we have said about the incision: and it should be that your incision is greater over the fracture site. And the more it extends from the fracture, the lesser the incision.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And let the threads be medium in thickness and fineness, and made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	For if the threads are thick, as I have seen in the operations of those placing stitches from twisted linen cords, it is a great error: for the incision falls outside the proper quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And thin threads again do not suit: for with them you will not achieve what you wish through the incision.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And it should not be that there is less than a finger's width between the astellae.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	If the patient is injured at the edges of the astellae after the incision in the healthy tissue, then place something soft such as fine cloth or woolen padding under them until nothing is injured from that.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	When there is a fracture with a wound, and there occurs a disruption in the skin, I treat it with reference to the chapter according to its singularity.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And know that not every fractured limb should be bound with straps from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	What is, because when a limb is large, you should not place straps on it from the first day, but only after five days, or seven, or more, according to your security regarding the risk of a hot abscess.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the method of ointments, which the ancients used and applied over fractures and dislocations.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	¶ The method of the abbreviated common ointment, which restores fractures and is suitable for many complexions, particularly women and children: for it is composed of ingredients that neither overcome heat nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And take from the powder of the mill, which is the flour meal that hangs on the walls of the mill near the motion of the millstone; and prepare it as it is, except that sift it with fine sieves and mix in some bran. And place the prepared mixture neither too thick nor too thin.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	¶ The method of another ointment, which restores fractures, dislocations, and twists.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Recipe almond, laurel, acacia, and enula, and juice of myrrh amounting to ʒ X, and aloes amounting to ʒ V of each, and alethil ʒ XX. All are to be ground and sifted, and mixed with alethil water: or with bran if the patient's complexion is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then apply this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	For it is of good composition, restores broken bones quickly, and benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	¶ Method of applying another plaster, which also benefits fractures and twists.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Recipe mugath, and mess, and white aloes, all amounting to 10 myrrh, and aloes of both kinds amounting to 5, acacia to 6, and Armenian gum to 20. All these are ground together, sieved, and prepared with water or white wine: and administered.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	¶ Method of applying a plaster for joints and bones separated from their places: and it soothes the pain that occurs in them, and the裂痕和骨折。
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Take the spent wool, immerse it in vinegar and decanted oil, and apply it to the place.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	And in this plaster there is no virtue of restoration, but it is good for soothing a hot abscess: and it expels pain properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	¶ Method of applying the plaster that restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take the leaves of figs for deafness, and the leaves of pawpaw tree: bruise all together, and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	¶ Method of applying a simplified plaster for the restoration of bone fractures: and when you wish to promote the resolution of remaining abscesses.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Recipe root of white alcaucal, camomile, violet flowers, and herb flour, all amounting to one part: grind all together, and prepare with wine if the limb is not already heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	If it is a fomentation, then prepare it with water of coriander moist or with water, and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	¶ The mode of applying a stronger plaster for the resolution of an apostema that occurs during the restoration of a member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris violarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	Use the entire preparation according to the heat of the member and the calmness of its warmth.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	Hippocrates, however, did not say in his book that anything should be placed on a broken member during its restoration, unless it is a caerote made from caera and oil: nothing else. He narrated that there should be a medium between thickness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	Galeno, however, has said that things should be placed on a broken member during its restoration, in which there is the application of substances for the removal of heat, such as myrrh, aloes, and frankincense, and similar substances as we have narrated.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	¶ The mode of applying a plaster that aids in healing and relieving pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Recipe mugath, and chickpeas, and hairs of a man's beard or feathers of a bird, and coriander seeds, and salt, parts equal: grind them, sift them, and prepare them: and make from this a plaster.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	The quantity, however, in which it is necessary that the ligature remain, and then be dissolved, is this: consider then, if no pain, nor itching, nor displacement of the fractured bone from its place occurs to the sick person: then do not dissolve it on many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If itching intense, or disturbing pain, or swelling occurs in that place: then hasten, and dissolve it at once on that day, and remove the plaster from it. And take a soft cloth, or a mild sea sponge, moistened, and submerge it in warm water, and wash the area with it until the itching subsides and the pain is relieved.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then let the limb rest for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then place over it wool soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose oil, and ligature it above it for one night until you are secure from the hot suppuration, and the swelling of the limb subsides, and the pain is relieved.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then repeat this until the constriction is fine and the plaster is small. And do not apply the constriction or fine ligature at first until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see that the suppuration, redness, pain, swelling, and all other symptoms have been completely removed, and you need plaster and constriction, then repeat that as you did at first equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	If nothing from what we have said occurs in the limb, then do not dissolve it until after three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when that which is dissolved is removed after twenty days, according to what appears to you from the dissolution of the limb, as we have said, until the fracture adheres and coagulation of the flesh approaches above it: then add to the constriction more than your first constriction entirely. And add in the engorgement of food by the sick person, according to what preceded its recollection.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	If you see the place of the fracture already drying up and becoming more attenuated than it should: then know that nutrition is prohibited from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Embroid the same with warm water at every place where you apply it to the same, and let it be applied for all three days, and loosen the bandage slightly.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	By this operation, nutrition runs to the limb, and it is quickly cured.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	That which the foolish restorers do to a fractured limb with another place, when it is not restored first as it should be and then according to its tortuosity, is an error from their operation and great fear: and if it were correct, the ancients would have said so in their books, and they would have operated on it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I have nowhere seen their trace in this entirely, and it is better that this not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	On the treatment of accidents in the head.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	The species of fractures are diverse, and its figures are many: and the causes of it are distinct.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	For there is a fracture that results from being struck with an axe, and the blow removes part of the bone as far as the periosteum, which is beneath the bone, just as a chisel cuts through wood: and for this reason, this species of fracture is called axiale.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or the sword strikes a part of the bone and cuts its surface without penetrating to its deepest part: and this species of fracture is called calanna, that is, leuatio or levation.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And it is a wound of two fractures, either great or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And from fracture is that which is contrition or attrition: and its cause is percussion with a stone, or falling upon a stone, or similar.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this fracture is also penetrating, which now approaches the panniculus, which is beneath the bone: or it is in the face of the bone: and it is a wound of these two fractures, either great or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And from fracture is that which is occult in the bone in subtlety of hair: and it is a small fissure, and for this reason it is named this species of fracture Capillaris.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And from these is the fracture which is caused by accident or percussion with a stone, and similar things that cause the lamina of the bone to enter the interior, and it forms a depression: as happens to brass workers when they are struck, and a part of them enters the interior.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	And this happens most often in the heads of wet bones, as are the heads of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And these fractures of all these species are separated and I will treat them with recall of that entire discussion in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we recognize all these species of fracture through examination of them, and inquiry into them with probes, and the removal of corrupt flesh that is above them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	The species Capillaris is recognized because it is detected above the bone, and is cleaned and applied with hot wax over it: for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	In the treatment of a fracture, first consider the patient's condition: then if you see from the symptoms one that signifies clearly beyond fear, such as vomiting of cholera, extension, loss of intellect, loss of voice, syncope, acute fever, and discharge from the eyes, and their redness, and similar symptoms in many dispositions, undoubtedly he is not cured: and if you see symptoms that do not terrify you, and hope for health: then begin his treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	If it happens that a wounded person comes to you when he is wounded first: and this is in the winter days, then it is necessary that you study for the removal of the bone before the fourteenth day according to every disposition.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it is in the days of summer, then it is necessary that you hasten to remove the bone before the seventh day, lest what is beneath the bone from the pus corrupt, and those accidents which we have narrated occur.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	And if the fracture of the bone has already reached the membrane touching the brain, and is accompanied by small pieces and suction: then it is necessary that you incise the broken and worn part, according to what I tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And you should scrape the head of the wound and detect above the bone in whatever manner is possible to you: and according to the shape of the wound, and what is slight above the patient.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	And if you happen to find during the detection of the bone a flow of blood, or a hot abscess: then apply to it what is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And you should fill the area with damp cloths in wine and rose oil: and make the wound rest until the abscess settles, and be free from the flow of blood.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin with the treatment of bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And this is done according to one of the two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	One method is this: cut the bone with an Incisor of sharp acie: and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Then administer the Incisor of another kind after the Incisor is wider slightly: and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then administer also the Incisor of another kind wider than the second.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	And the second method is this: you should have a number of different Incisores; some wider than others, and some shorter than others. Their extremities should be sharpened to the utmost degree, and made of iron or steel. Use them with care in striking over the Incisor, so that they do not shake the head and injure it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	If however the bone is strong and hard, then you must bore around it before you administer Incisores, using Terebris called non profundantia. And they are not so named because they do not penetrate beyond the boundary of the bony flesh to what is behind them; for their extremity is round above that which is under their head, acute like a margin, and a small circle prevents submerging and penetrating the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	And it suits you to take a number of these Terebris, each one suited to the thickness of the bone, until there is a Terebrum for every cranium. The length and brevity of its acute extremity should be according to the thickness of that cranium.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the form of three species of Terebrorum, or Trepanorum.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	The quality of boring in the circumference of a fractured bone is this: you shall place the Trebucket over the hole and turn it with your fingers until you know that the bone is already penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then exchange the Trebucket to another place, and place what is between all the hole and the size of the radius, or about that size.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then incise with Incisors what is between all the hole from the bone: and make it finer than you can above that from the end of levity, as we said, until you remove the bone, either by hand or with some other instrument you have prepared for it: such as tweezers and fine tongs.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And you must be careful with every precaution, so that the Trebucket or any Incisor from the siphac does not touch anything.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When therefore you encircle the hole to bore it and separate it from the siphac, if it is continuous with it and you extract it, you must scrape and level the end that remains in the bone with another similar Incisor.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	Indeed, it must be finer and more subtle than other Incisors.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	If there remains anything from small bones, take it with facility, together with what is at your disposal among the instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then care for the wound after this with licenses and ointments as we have said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	And another method of operation is easy, quite remote from fear: which Galen said and praised highly: and this is his word.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	It is necessary for you first to begin by exposing the portion of the bone in the place where the fracture is more severe and clearer; until when you have exposed that part, and placed under it the extremity of this lenticular Incisor, whose form is as follows.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the lenticular part is soft and does not touch anything; and its acute part goes into both sides of it in length, as you see; so that the lenticular part is attached to the siphon, its face inclining acute towards the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike the Incisor with one hand using a small hammer until you cut through the entire bone smoothly, as it rotates. Be careful with the cloth to prevent anything unforeseen from happening that you fear entirely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the physician were not a more foolish man and less knowledgeable about it, nor asleep, then if anything remained attached to the bone from the cloth in certain places, it would be cut off from it with the extremity of that lenticular Incisor, and it would be freed from it smoothly.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	It is liberated from it without harm, and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the fracture of the bone does not penetrate to the cloth, and what is severed from the bone is its face, and roughnesses and thin scars remain in it: then you must scrape that roughness, and remove those thin scars with fine rasps which you have prepared in various quantities, so that it is possible for you to administer more suitable and more correct parts in every place, according to what the operation leads you, and the bone itself, and its form.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And you must apply according to your reason, wherein first the root of the bone, wider than their razors.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use the finer one afterwards.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And you must not cease to do this according to continuity until you arrive at administering something finer and more subtle than all of theirs.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	In each of the remaining small fissures and fine fractures, you must attend to it with care according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And it is a matter that is not hidden from anyone who has any study in this art, and it stands above what we have written and shown in major fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	And if a flap is retained when you remove the bone, then you must take a linen cloth, according to the size of the wound, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another cloth, either doubled or tripled, and immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it over the first cloth: and make it as easy to do as you can so that it does not burden the splint.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then apply a broad ligament above it: and do not tighten it unless with the amount that holds the wound only: and remove it with this care after one day, or two days, until you are secure from the hot suppuration.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then remove it and apply medicines after that to combat excessive dryness, such as roots of lily, powder of herb, dust of incense, aristolochia, and similar substances: and you should make a powder from these medicines, which is sprinkled over the wound as if it were dry.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And universally administer in it all medicine of its property to cleanse and not bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And beware according to your virtue, that the wound in your cure be clear: neither let there be filth of ointment nor foulness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	Neither let the virus aggregate therein at all: for when the virus aggregates over the cerumenous cloth, it corrupts it and putrefies it, and evil follows upon the patient after that great mischief: and now it has happened in a croup of the head, when the orifice is cleansed from it, especially when the care thereof is neglected, blackness on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	Therefore consider then, if accidents occur to the patient which we have said, know that it is undoubtedly harmful.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if blackness does not occur, unless from medicine which is placed upon it, and is of the virtue of that medicine, to cause that blackness: then you must take one part from honey, three parts from rose oil, and lines with them a cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then place it over the croup: thereafter cure it with the remedies that are suitable until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	¶ On the Restoration of the Nose When Broken.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Know that the nose is broken only by two of its upper parts together or by one of them: for they are two bones. For the lower part is cartilaginous and does not break; and injury to it happens only through friction and distortion and similar conditions.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of the two parts is broken, then it must be that you introduce a small finger into the nostril and equalize that fracture with your index finger and little finger outside, until the nose returns to its natural shape: and this shall be done by art with facility.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And beware that no pain occurs to the patient through your operation.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and the finger does not reach that place, then it must be that you equalize with the extremity of the radius, on which there is a small prominence.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If the fracture is in both parts, then make it similar to that of the other side: and hasten with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then on the seventh or tenth day after the abscess has subsided in peace.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then introduce into the end of the nose a ligament of linen if the fracture is in one part: or introduce two ligaments if the fracture is in both parts: and let the thickness of the ligament be such that it fills the nostril.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some ancient restorers said that the ligaments should be infused in butter and be changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	That, however, does not seem advisable to me; rather, it should be infused in a paste of alum and ground flour.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then remove the ligament once the nose has become firm and the cartilage has hardened.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And at times introduce a goose feather into the nose in place of the ligament, after a soft cloth has enveloped it: and this itself holds the nasal fracture more strongly, and ensures that the patient is not prevented from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	And this is not a necessary thing.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish, do that; and if you wish, do the licensing.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	And if a hot abscess occurs again while you are operating on Naso, plaster his nose with crocodile dung, or with a mixture infused in rose oil, or a moderate amount of dyactive.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	And if a hot abscess does not occur, then you should plaster it with sesame flour, and dust it with powdered frankincense mixed with alum.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Then apply a gentle suppository, and do not tie up Naso's nose at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	And if the bones of Naso's fracture are broken or crushed, then you should split them open and extract them using appropriate instruments.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then close the incision, and care for it with plaster or ointments that are suitable for healing and strengthening.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	And if a wound occurs on Naso's nose, then you should treat it with licorice: and administer a lead tube until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	¶ On the Restoration of the Lower Jaw When It Is Broken.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	And if the lower jaw is broken and its fracture is not accompanied by a wound: then see whether it is a fracture on the outer side only, and not broken into two parts, and treat it internally: then its diagnosis is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	Therefore, if the fracture is on the right side, you must insert your left index finger into the patient's mouth: similarly, if the fracture is on the left mandible, then insert your right index finger: and push with it the hump of the fracture inwardly with ease through the finger, and from the inside part of the bone with your other hand to the exterior in a balanced manner.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the fracture of the jaw has already separated into two parts, then you must administer extension from both parts, according to the straightness: until an equalization of it is possible.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If, however, there has already been a loosening or disruption of the teeth: then bind those you hope will remain with a thread of gold, or silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then place over the fractured jaw caerotum.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then place over it a doubled cloth, and place over the cloth a large splint made centered: or a piece of sole leather equal in length to the jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then bind it from above, according to how the binding is prepared for you and suits its application, until it is not destroyed: and command the patient to rest in tranquility and quietness: and place his food as sips of mild liquids.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If, however, you estimate that something has altered in its figure in any manner: then hurry and remove it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then correct what has been altered from that, and apply a plaster with flour of mill, mixed with white wine, or with sesame flour, after you have removed the caerotum: and place over the plaster soft wool.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While therefore that plaster remains attached over it, and the disposition of the bone is not altered, let it be removed, do not dissolve it, until it is healed: or bind the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	This fracture is bound three times in seven weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If meanwhile a hot abscess occurs, then administer what we have said many times for the suppression of it until that abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if there is a fracture with a wound, consider.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	For the fragment of bone is now separated from the wound or from the seat: then use fine forceps here, so as to remove those fragments along with what suits you for their removal from the instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If the wound opening is constricted, then dilate it with a lancet according to the amount needed.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have removed those fragments, and nothing remains of them, then the wound opening, if it is large: and if not, apply over it from the plasters which suit that, and cause it to flesh over until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	¶ On the Restoration of the Furcula, When It Is Fractured.
Caput VI.	Caput VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	Indeed, the furcula is most often fractured from the anterior part of the humerus, and its fracture occurs according to one of three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	For it is sometimes fractured and separated into two parts, besides what may occur at the seat of the fracture: and this is easier to restore.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or thus, what occurs in the bone of satagiae: and it is more difficult for restoration.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or thus, what is a fracture with wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And the operation in such a case when the fracture is without wound, is that you make two attendants present, one of whom holds the assistant's piece which follows the broken fork, and the other extends the neck towards the part.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then adjust the fracture with your fingers until it takes the proper form: and let there be neither prominence nor concavity in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If you need more extension, then you must place under the patient's broken part a sphere of cloth or wool, and its size should be according to the necessity you have: and extend and elevate the fork, and compress the sphere with your hand until you adjust the fracture as required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you cannot draw the extremity of the fork toward the exterior because it has reached the depth, then you must have the patient's head turned backward on his own neck, and place a medium pillow under his shoulder in proportion to its size. A attendant should press the patient's shoulder downward until the end of the fork, which is deep, is raised upward. Then adjust the fracture and align it with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If you feel the satagium from the fork and it moves, then you must locate it and draw out the satagium with facility.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If it is retained in the bone, then make a incision in it with one of the Incisor instruments which you have prepared for that purpose, after you have placed under the fork an instrument that saves the satagium. This instrument is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It is assimilated to the cochlea which does not have concavity.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	And its width should be according to what you need of it from the size of the bone and its thickness.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	And its length should be according to what is possible for you for the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And may it have two ends, as you see: and one end may be broad, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If, however, the wound rupture which you tore when you extracted the satḥāʾ bone is wide, and you are secure from a hot apostema: then join the two wound edges with stitches.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the rupture is small, or you fear a hot apostema: then fill the wound with cloths and lint according to the size of the wound.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	And if a hot apostema occurs, then soak the cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and place it over it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	And if the bone stricture is without a wound and without a section, you should place over it a paste made from flour with alum.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And place a soft plaster over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a sphere under its shade if you need that.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take the himayta, that is, the long wheel which the Saracens use: and let its width be that of one palm, or about that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a doubled pledget over the stencil and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take a blade from a thin board, whose width shall be three fingers, and similarly in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it in cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then wrap the cloth with the blade in the wound that falls over the fracture and place it.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the wound over the fracture as it is rolled up, and wrap it around his neck, and under the healthy side of his forehead, and under the unhealthy side of his forehead: and reduce it to all parts, and as you see that the tension holds the fracture in proper alignment: and this is that which is not hidden from you, and wholly, so that the blade does not protrude from above the mouth of the fracture.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And for this reason, you must examine the patient daily.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Therefore, whenever the ligament softens, and you see the blade has been removed, then straighten it out and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place the patient's pillow on his back, and put a small pledget under the healthy side of his forehead at night, so that the auxiliary support is raised from the affected side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Therefore, the fracture of the furcula will be elevated through the elevation of the humerus.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Or ligate his arm to his neck: and do not release the ligament unless an accident occurs due to itching or from an abscess, up to twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then renew the plaster, if you see his face turn to that.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And apply in the stricture, and release it until it is restored and coagulated.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	And the fracture of the furcula is tightened and strengthened for the most part in twenty days: sometimes it happens in some people in less time.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	¶ On the Restoration of the Fracture of the Spatula.
Caput VII.	Head VII.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	The spatula rarely fractures, and if it does, it is at the wide part of its location: and only the edges are fractured.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	When therefore it is fractured at that place and in the middle of it, and is not recognized except by touch: then according to its fracture prepare its treatment.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	And reduce it to the natural figure in every way possible that is within your skill.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	Then place above the area powder from the mill with alum wine, and gentle plaster, and place on top lint from doubled cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	Then place above it a wide strip from a thin board according to the size of the entire spatula, or slightly larger.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	If there is indeed a concavity in any part of the spatula beneath the strip, then level that concavity with gentle plaster until the strip descends evenly.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	Then bind above with long ligature, a suitable compression and firmness of the strip, until it does not remove from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	And consider the ligament every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Whichever time the ligament is softened, tighten it, and if an equal piece is removed from its place: let the sick person lie on his healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	And the spatula is restored in twenty days, or in twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	When this number is completed, then release the ligament: and you shall be in safety.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	For itself is from the bones whose union is not feared, nor their dissolution.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	If it proceeds from the bone in fragments and pricks beneath the skin: then cut above it, and remove it.
